Dialogue.Stage Direction: A scene of mud and desolation. The Tardis materialises in a puddle, and Jamie steps out into it. Zoe is sensibly wearing a trench coat, jodhpurs and knee high boots.

Dialogue.Line: What a place.
Where are we? Earth?
Well, it looks like it, Zoe. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They pick their way over and up a slope. The Doctor whistles 'A-hunting we will go' happily to himself.

Dialogue.Line: What's this stuff?
Aye, wee spikes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie pricks his finger.

Dialogue.Line: Barbed wire, Jamie. It's filthy stuff. I thought so.
Eh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pulls a tin helmet from underneath some wood.

Dialogue.Line: Where are we?
We're back in history, Jamie. One of the most terrible times on the planet Earth.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Whee, boom!

Dialogue.Line: Quick! Down there!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They dive into a nearby bomb crater in the ground. Another shell explodes nearby as Jamie stands to watch.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: More explosions and machine gun fire. They get splattered with soil. An army ambulance comes trundling up through the explosions, then suddenly all goes quiet. A woman in a great coat is standing by the crater.

Dialogue.Line: I say, are you all right?
Well, yes, I think so.
I shouldn't stay around here if I were you. That was just the softening up barrage.
What?
Eh?
Oh. Oh my. Oh.
What on earth are you doing here, anyway? This is no place for civilians.
Well, where are we?
Between the lines, I think. Not quite sure myself. I'm heading for Ypres, but I seem to have got

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two soldiers in gas masks are standing next to them.

Dialogue.Line: Hände hock. Raus schnell.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The four are taken at gunpoint to the ambulance and driven off. Buckingham is behind the wheel. Further on, two men come running over a rise. Buckingham stops the ambulance. The officer puts his revolver to the German's head.

Dialogue.Line: Out you come.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Played by  David Savile. I used to have such a crush on him.

Dialogue.Line: There's another in the back.
Take care of him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs leaves his soldier covering the man up front and goes to the back of the ambulance. Jamie and the Doctor have already overpowered the other German.

Dialogue.Line: Well done. Get inside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The British and German soldiers are bundled into the back. Carstairs sits next to Buckingham up front.

Dialogue.Line: Who are those people?
No idea. Picked them up in no man's land.
Well, I suppose we'd better get them back to base.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adjoining the trench, Captain Blackadder is reporting up the telephone line. Explosions are heard almost constantly.

Dialogue.Line: They've laid down a heavy barrage all along the line. I think that they're after that ammo dump. Don't worry, sir. We'll hold out.
Sir?
What is it?
Ambulance approaching, sir.
Give it protective fire. Jump to it. man!
Sir.
Hold your fire! Hold it. Come on. Come on. Get down, get down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe makes her way behind the troops firing over the top of the trench as Carstairs helps Buckingham, the Doctor and Jamie down.

Dialogue.Line: Couple of prisoners, Sergeant. My men are bringing them in.
Very good, sir.
How are we going to get back to the Tardis?
Now, just be quiet, Jamie, and let me do the talking.
Sir?
What is it now?
With the ambulance, sir, there was a Lieutenant.
Well, bring him in.
Sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Sergeant leaves, Carstairs enters.

Dialogue.Line: Lieutenant Carstairs, sir.
What are you doing here? You don't belong to this battalion, do you?
No. Patrolling in no mans land, sir. I got cut off from my own lot.
What were you doing traipsing about in ambulances?
Recaptured it from the Hun, sir. Lucky we arrived, really. There was a WVR driving it, and three civilians inside.
Civilians? In no man's land?
Your sergeant's taking care of them, sir.
Good grief. Civilians.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The travellers have been given mugs of tea.

Dialogue.Line: The thing is, where are we?
Early 20th century isn't it, Doctor?
Yes. I'm afraid that we've landed up in the middle of one of the worst wars in human history.
What are they dug into the ground like this for?
Well, it's trench warfare, you see, Jamie. These trenches stretch right the way across the continent of Europe.
Well, what are they fighting for?
Well, I well I believe that they call it The War to End Wars.
Do you think they'll let us go?
Well, they've got no reason to keep us. Here, things have calmed down a bit. Let's try and get away.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But as soon as he puts his head up over the top of the trench, machine gun fire.

Dialogue.Line: Oh!
What do you think you're doing?
Our transportation is over there, you see. We're trying to get to it.
Over there? There's nothing over there but Huns. Anyway, the Major wants to see you.
Oh, we don't want to bother him. I'm sure he's very busy.
Come on! You too, ma'am, if you don't mind.
Right, sir. We'll go over the top at oh four hundred hours. Sir. As you say, sir. Well, that was General Smythe. Big push tomorrow. How long have you been out here?
Well, sir, it's odd, but I can't quite remember.
I know. It seems like forever, doesn't it?
Civilian party, sir. Major Barrington, ma'am.
How do you do, er?
Jennifer Buckingham.
Ah. I understand you picked these people up in no man's land?
Yes. Found them hiding in a bomb crater.
I see. May I ask you what you were doing there?
Trying not to get killed.
I see. You're a Highlander, aren't you? Why aren't you with your regiment?
Regiment? I'm not in the army.
Are you a deserter?
No, of course not! I
All right, all right. And you, what are you doing in the front line? No place for young ladies.
Well what about her?
This lady's a WVR. She's here on duty.
Er, look, Major, we don't want to trouble you. If you'd just let us go on our way.
And which way is that?
He tried to make off towards the German line, sir.
Did he, by jove.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Whee, Boom! Bits of ceiling come down.

Dialogue.Line: I think General Smythe would like to know about you. (into telephone) Get me General Smythe at base.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The General sits at a simple folding table in a once great stately home, talking into a field telephone.

Dialogue.Line: Civilians? In no man's land? Yes. Well, send them back here at once. I'll question them myself.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The General's adjutant enters.

Dialogue.Line: Three civilians found in no man's land.
Good lord. Whereabouts, sir?
Barrington's sector. He's sending them straight back here. I'm going to turn in for half an hour.
Sir.
Let me know when these civilians arrive.
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The obligatory mug of tea arrives.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you, Sergeant Major.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A wood panelled room with a large trunk on its end in the corner. Smythe reaches for a portrait on the wall when the door opens. It's the Sergeant Major with his mug of tea.

Dialogue.Line: Don't ever come through that door without knocking! Get out!
Right, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He leaves. Smythe reaches for the portrait again and it swings open on hinges to reveal a circular monitor and a dial. Smythe turns it on.

Dialogue.Line: Smythe, 1917 zone, British sector. Reinforcements urgently required. At least five thousand specimens.
But look, Major Barrington, if only you'd let us get back to our transportation we'd be no further nuisance to you.
I'm sorry, you must first go to the Chateau and give a proper account of yourselves. For all I know you may be spies.
Oh look, we keep trying to tell you, you daft sassenach.
Hold your tongue, man!
No, I won't!
Now please! Don't let us lose our tempers.
Supply truck leaving for base now, sir.
Good. Get them onto it. Off you go.
Now, just a moment, we're not going back to any base. Now, come on.
Sentry!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie's exit is stopped by a soldier and rifle.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, I think perhaps we'd better do as they say.
I'm glad one of you is showing some sense. All right, Sergeant, take them away.
Yes, sir.
I'm sure you'll be all right. Anyway, good luck.
Oh, thank you very much.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Jamie and Zoe leave with the Sergeant.

Dialogue.Line: Now then, what are we going to do about you two?
Could your men do something about my ambulance? It's bogged down just over the hill.
Yes, soon get that out for you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barrington leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Funny about those people. They didn't look like spies.
Spies never do. I don't envy them if they are. General Smythe can be pretty ruthless. Know what my chaps call him?
No.
The Butcher.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Jamie and Zoe are marched under escort into a large room in a faded and dilapidated Chateau. A Sergeant Major gives the orders.

Dialogue.Line: Right, left, right, left, right, left, right. Prisoners and escort, mark time! Halt! Right turn! Civilian prisoners from Major Barrington, sir.
All right. At ease.
Stand at ease!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie stamps his foot to the side, stepping on the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: At ease.
The General wants to question you personally.
Oh good. I'm sure we'll be able to explain everything to his satisfaction.
Look, how long are we going to be kept here?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The room is empty.

Dialogue.Line: Sir?
Take them to the cells, Sergeant Major.
But I thought you said we were going to see the General?
The General is not available. Take them away.
Prisoners and escort, attention! Right turn!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: No, the other right, Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: By the front, quick march. Left, right, left, right.
There's no need to keep shouting at us, you know.
Left, right, left, right, left.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs pours himself some tea from a billy can.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, I'm sorry, do you want some more?
Thanks.
Where is your hospital?
Oh, it's not far.
Whereabouts?
Well, you're going to think me awfully silly, but I can't quite remember.
Don't worry, it'll come back to you. Memory's a funny thing out here. Can't always remember things myself.
What kinds of things?
Oh, silly things. Names, dates, how long I've been here. Sometimes wonder if I've got a touch of the old shell shock. Have you talked to anybody else about it?
Haven't liked to. One feels so stupid.
Yes. Still, it is rather worrying not being able to remember things.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The telephone rings.

Dialogue.Line: Ah. Suppose I'd better answer that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barrington rushes in and takes the receiver from Carstairs.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, thanks, old man. Major Barrington. Yes. Right, sir. We're wanted at HQ. Some sort of enquiry to do with those civilians you brought in.
How long will it take? I'm bound to be needed back at the hospital.
We just got your ambulance out of the mud. We'll all go in that, and then you can go straight on from HQ. Are you ready?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: No bottles, just racks and barrels.

Dialogue.Line: And you'll not pick that lock with a hairgrip either.
These walls are solid stone. There's just no way out.
Now what do we do, then?
It's just a temporary misunderstanding, Jamie. We'll get it cleared up when we see the General.
Why should he listen to us? No one else has.
Ah, they were all obeying orders, Zoe. That's the military mind.
We must have looked a bit suspicious. Three civilians in the middle of a war?
Aye, well, I just hope that General does listen to us.
Oh, yes, I expect he's a very nice chap.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe comes out of his room.

Dialogue.Line: Got those reports yet?
Just finished now, sir.
Thank you.
By the way, sir, those three civilians have turned up. I've got them in the cells.
Oh, what of it?
As a matter of fact, I went into your room to tell you but

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe puts on his spectacles and stares at Ransom.

Dialogue.Line: I was asleep, Captain Ransom. You did not wish to disturb me.
Yes, sir, you were asleep. I didn't wish to disturb you.
That's right. Now, what did you make of these civilians?

Oh, two men and a young lady. According to Major Barrington they can't account for themselves. He seemed to think the younger lad was a deserter. Apparently the older man tried to make off for the enemy lines.
Sir! Major Barrington, sir.
Thanks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Sergeant Major leaves.

Dialogue.Line: This is Lady Jennifer Buckingham, sir, and Lieutenant.
How do you do. Do sit down.
Thank you.
Barrington, you know my adjutant, Ransom, don't you?
Yes, we, er, Ransom and I were er

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe puts on his spectacles.

Dialogue.Line: You were at school together. You were at school together.
Yes, that's right. How are you Ransom?
Now, Carstairs, tell me, where did you find these civilians?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Later the Kings Regulations and Orders for the Army, 1912 is opened. Ransom, Smythe and Barrington are at the little table as a Court Martial.

Dialogue.Line: Left, right, left, right. Escort and accused, mark time. Halt. left turn.
Major Barrington, how nice to see you.
Accused! Back in line.
If you are ready, gentlemen? March the prisoners forward, Sergeant Major.
Sir! Accused, one pace forward, march.
Now, look, what's going on here?
The Court Martial is now in session.
Court Martial? But we're civilians.
This whole area is under martial law.
Oh, yes, that may be, but if you'll allow me to explain, we were
You will have an opportunity of addressing the Court at the proper time.
Oh, thank you.
Now, the statements of Lieutenant Carstairs and Lady Jennifer have been taken into evidence. The prisoners waylaid an ambulance in no man's land
Waylaid? The ambulance found us.

The vehicle was later commandeered by a waiting enemy patrol. Recaptured by Lieutenant Carstairs, the prisoners insinuated themselves into a forward command post, where at the earliest opportunity one of them made a break for the enemy lines with whatever information he had gathered.
Oh, but none of that's true. You've twisted the whole thing.
This is a travesty of justice. What are we charged with?
In the case of this man, desertion from a Highland regiment.
But, but
In the case of yourself and the girl, the charge is one of espionage. The penalty for all these charges is death.
But this is monstrous!
We shall now hear the case for the defence. Have you anything to say?
Yes, I most certainly have! Am I allowed to question the witnesses?
Certainly. We wish to give you every opportunity to explain yourselves.
Thank you. Lady Jennifer, will you please explain to these gentlemen the circumstances of our meeting.
There's no need for that. It's in the statement. Next question.
What? Well, Lieutenant Carstairs, when your men recaptured the ambulance, wasn't it obvious to you we were prisoners of the Germans?
Has the defence finished with this witness?
Well, if you're not going to allow them to answer, what is the use?
Very well. Have you any explanation to offer before the Court passes sentence?
But you haven't heard anything yet. You don't really call this a trial, do you?
The Court will now consider it's verdict.
Hey, you haven't even asked me anything.
There's nothing to ask you. You are a deserter! March him away, Sergeant Major!
Sir. Escort and accused, left turn. Left wheel, by the front, quick march! Left, right, left, right. Halt!
I thought you were going to explain everything?
Well, he didn't give me a chance, did he. There's something very strangely wrong here.
Why has that General got it in for us? He seems determined to find us guilty.
Yes, but why?
I don't know. They seem pretty harmless to me.
Yes, there's no actual evidence of them actually spying on anything.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe puts on his spectacles.

Dialogue.Line: It is quite clear that they are all guilty. All guilty!
Yes, they're guilty. Knew it as soon as I looked at them.
There's clear evidence that they were spying.
Thank you, gentlemen. Well, I think we can resume. Sergeant Major, bring the prisoners back.
Escort and accused, left wheel! By the front, quick march. Left, right, left, right, left wheel. Mark time. Halt! Right turn!
The Court has carefully considered all of the evidence and finds you all guilty as charged. Desertion in a time of war is a most heinous military crime.
Look, I've deserted from nowhere! I was never in your rotten army.
You will be confined to a military barracks awaiting a regimental Court Martial.
Now look, I'm not being confined anywhere.
You, young lady, have betrayed your King and country. You are sentenced to ten years penal servitude to be spent in a civilian prison.
Oh but I haven't done anything!
The court finds you guilty of espionage. For a crime of this magnitude there is only one penalty.
But this is ridiculous! You know all the evidence has been twisted against us! Tell them!
The witnesses have given their evidence. The court has reached it's verdict. If you've nothing further to say, sentence will be passed.
I most certainly have something further to say! This is all just a mockery! I demand the right to appeal to a higher authority.
There is no right of appeal. You will be executed at dawn tomorrow. Take him away, Sergeant Major!
Prisoners and escort, left turn!
Now just a moment, you can't do this to us!
Hold him!
Let go!
Hand him over to the MPs. They'll take him to the military prison.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is taken away.

Dialogue.Line: I'll take these two back to the cell, sir.
Just a minute, Sergeant Major. Captain Ransom, surely you're not going to keep this poor girl in the cells all night?
Well, we've nowhere else to keep her.
Well, why not leave her here? I could look after her.
Yes, I don't see why not.
Thank you.
All right, put a guard on the door, Sergeant Major, and take him away.
Sir!
Oh I don't want to leave you, Doctor.
Now you stay here, Zoe. Goodbye, my dear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor kisses Zoe on the forehead and leaves with the Sergeant Major.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, can't you help us, Lieutenant Carstairs?
Nothing I can do, I'm afraid.
Well, nice to have met you both. Must be getting back. Goodbye, my dear. Chin up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barrington leaves.

Dialogue.Line: But you can't let them execute the Doctor. He hasn't done anything.
Well, you heard the evidence, my dear. It's all proved. I'm afraid he is a spy.
Left, right, left, right, left, right, left, right, left, right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is marched in.

Dialogue.Line: I'll see that they bring you something to eat.
Oh, thank you. Sergeant Major? Have you been at the front long?
Oh, quite a while. I've been out here since
What's the matter?
Can't remember. Here, what are you asking me all these questions for?
Sir?
Yes, what is it?
You wanted the keys to the prison cell.
Oh yes. Is everything arranged for the execution?
Yes.
Very well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ransom leaves. Smythe puts the keys under his pillow and lies down. A sentry checks on Zoe and Buckingham sleeping in chairs in the main room. Once he has gone, Zoe sneaks over to Smythe's room and goes inside. There is no one there. She discovers the monitor behind the portrait, then hunts for the keys, finds them and leaves.
The Doctor hides behind the door when he hears it being unlocked.

Dialogue.Line: Zoe!
Oh Doctor!
How on Earth?
Well, I couldn't leave you to be shot, could I? It's dawn.
Oh, what a nice and clever girl you are. Now, we must find Jamie. They said something about a military prison.
Yes.
Come on.
Quite right, Doctor. It is time to go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gunshot. The Doctor tenses up for the pain but it is a soldier who has been injured. There is a sniper in one of the barns nearby.

Dialogue.Line: Divert!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The firing squad scatter to try and get the sniper. The soldier guarding Zoe is hit and she runs to free the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Well done, Zoe. Can you undo it?
Oh, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe unties him.

Dialogue.Line: Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe is reporting to his controllers.

Dialogue.Line: I am leaving for the conference now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe turns off the monitor and closes the portrait over it. There is a Tardis-like sound as a large metal object appears in the corner of the room and an entrance slides forward from the centre. Ransom enters.

Dialogue.Line: General Smythe, the prisoners have
Ransom, get out!
Sir, what?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe puts on his spectacles.

Dialogue.Line: There is nothing there. You can see nothing.
No, sir, there's nothing there.
You have not seen me. I have been called away to an important meeting.
Important meeting. Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe goes into the SIDRAT, for that is what it is, the door closes and it dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: General Smythe? Oh, of course, he's gone to that meeting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Still not a proper cell, but with barbed wire wrapped around the bars in the door grille.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, do I not get any breakfast?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two guards throw another man in with Jamie. Dishevelled but still wearing his powdered wig...

Dialogue.Line: Redcoat? What are you doing here?
Highlander! Keep away from me, you!
Hey, easy now. I'm a prisoner too, you know! How'd you get here? Well, come on, how did you get here?
I don't know, I can't remember! I got lost, I think.
What year do you think it is?
Year? Why, it's seventeen forty five.
Sss?!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor uses his telescope to spy out a set of heavily guarded farm buildings complete with machine gun emplacements.

Dialogue.Line: Oh yes. Yes. Yes, that's it. That's the military prison, all right. That's where Jamie'll be. Take a look. The trouble is those sentries.
What are we going to do?
Don't know. I shall have to think of something. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They run down a slope to a road where a staff car is driving along. The Doctor flags it down.

Dialogue.Line: Stop! And about time too! Where have you been?
Eh?
You were sent to meet us!
Meet who?
Now don't argue! Take us to the prison! In you get, Miss Heriot. Well, drive on!
Look, you must try and remember!
I've told you. I was fighting up in the Highlands, I got lost and I don't. There was this mist.
Uh huh.
It came down all round me. The next thing I knew, everything was different.
Well, how do you mean, different?
Well, there were these great big guns, bigger than I'd ever seen before, and carts moving along without horses.
Aye, I've seen those too. Now, go on, go on.
Well, then these fellows in the funny uniforms, they came along, and they caught me and brought me here. Where are we?
I don't know. But I've got to get to the Doctor. Look, and you're going to help me.
Oh, no! I don't trust you. You're one of them rebels!
Now look, just you listen to me a moment.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie advances on the Redcoat with a wheel spoke in his hand.
Farmhouse kitchen, actually. Another officer on another field telephone.

Dialogue.Line: Who? Civilians? Well, tell them to wait. I'm having my tea.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But barely has he taken a sip when -

Dialogue.Line: How dare you treat me like this, sir!
What? Who the blazes are you?
Don't you address me like that, sir! This is disgraceful! I shall make a complaint directly to the Minister himself!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: That would be Lord Derby.

Dialogue.Line: Minister? Oh, I don't understand. Who are you?
I'm the examiner from the War Office, I'm here to inspect the military prison. This young lady is my secretary. Well, you were expecting us, surely?
Well, there must be some mistake. I mean, can I see your identification papers?
How dare you! You send no car to meet us on our arrival, and now you add insult to injury by doubting my credentials! Do you know who I am, sir?
Well, I'm terribly sorry and all that. It's probably my adjutant's fault. Would you care for some tea?
We are here to inspect the security arrangements of the prison. Now I suggest we stop wasting time and get on with it!
Not a trace of them. General Smythe'll be furious. We must get those people back.
Yes, of course, sir.
Now, you're got to help me, both of you. Get a party from my sergeant and search this building.
Yes, sir.
I'll take a patrol towards the German lines.
What shall I do?
I'd like you to stay here and man the telephone. I've put out an alert and someone might phone in some information. All right, Carstairs?
Yes, sir!
Lady Jennifer, if the General returns perhaps you'd explain what has happened?
Certainly. Where's he gone?
He's been called away to an urgent meeting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ransom leaves.

Dialogue.Line: I know it's an awful thing to say but I can't help hoping they get away.
I know just how you feel. Still
Carstairs!
Excuse me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Redcoat has Jamie on the floor, struggling.

Dialogue.Line: Help me, guard! He's trying to
You're right, I'll kill you!
He's trying to kill me! Stop it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two guards rush in and haul the Redcoat off Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: Get off him!
Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie rams the wheel spoke into the sergeant's belly then punches his lights out while the Redcoat first knees then hits the other.

Dialogue.Line: You fight very well, for a redcoat.
All right, Corporal. I'll tell the Captain.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs enters.

Dialogue.Line: Any luck?
Not a sign.
That was one of the patrol posts. Nothing to report.
Poor old Ransom. He's in for a sticky time when the General gets back.
Didn't you think that there was something rather strange about that court martial?
Oh well, military justice, you know. It's not like the Old Bailey.
No, but, you remember we were talking about not remembering things?
Yes?
Well, things are starting to come back to me.
What sort of things?

Well, I was on my way to the hospital, well behind the lines. I was driving through a forest and all of a sudden there was a strange sort of mist. Fog. And then I was in a field dressing station looking after some wounded soldiers.
Hmm. Loss of memory.
No, but isn't it strange that you should to be suffering from it too?
Mist!
What about it?
I wonder, could it be some kind of new gas? If perhaps the Germans have invented a new type of poison gas, one that affects our minds.
And finally, on the outer perimeter there are the concealed tripwires and the patrols.
Ah.
Certainly does look escape proof.
I'd like to see your records.
What? Oh yes, they're over here. You won't find anything wrong there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gorton hands over a huge ledger.

Dialogue.Line: I sincerely hope not.
There you are.
Oh, yes.
Arrivals.
Yes.
Lengths of sentences. Discharges.
Yes, arrivals. Latest arrival, Scottish deserter awaiting return to his regiment. Possible to talk to a prisoner?
Well, er, it's very irregular. However, for you I'm sure that I can arrange (The telephone rings.)
Excuse me. Gorton here. What? Escaped! Well, get onto it right away, man. Let me know as soon as you've got them.
Is something the matter, Commandant?
Er, nothing important.
Did I hear you say that someone had escaped?
Oh well, as a matter of fact, yes. Two chaps. One of them was the Scotsman that you were talking about.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and the Redcoat skirt along a wall, but when they have to step out into the open they are spotted.

Dialogue.Line: Halt or we fire!
Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards fire their revolvers.

Dialogue.Line: Shot? Both of them? I see, right. Keep me informed. That's one of them. Shot while trying to escape.
Shot? Well, which one was it? The Highlander?
No, but does it matter?
Matter? Why, of course it matters! Shooting down prisoners? Why, it's barbaric!
But they were trying to escape!
Well, that's no excuse for murder! I want the other man brought here.
What for?
I'm not satisfied. I want to hear the prisoner's side of the story.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is dragged along by two guards, his feet not touching the ground, and pushed into the kitchen.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
We'll see you get a doctor if you need one, my man. Right, let him go. Commandant, dismiss your man.
Carry on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The MP leaves.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?
Speak when you're spoken to! Now then, what's all this about trying to escape?
What are you up to?
I'm not concerned with that! What about the other man you escaped with?
Oh, he was shot in the leg, and they were going to shoot me, too.
I see. This is very serious. I shall have to make a full report.
But they were trying to escape! My men had no alternative but to shoot.
We'll see what General Smythe has to say about that . GORTON: Indeed we will!
What are you doing?
I'm going to telephone General Smythe. I've had about all I can take from you, sir. General Smythe.
Ah, you'll regret this. The Minister
I don't care two hoots about the Minister. Besides, I'm not even sure you're from the War Office. Yes, where are your identity papers?
My identity papers?
I thought so. I thought there was a fishy story all along. Hello, is that

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe smashes a vase of flowers down onto Gorton's head.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry, Doctor, but it seemed the only way.
Oh, well done, Zoe. Yes, I think he'll survive. Right, come on. Let's see if we can bluff our way out of here.
Yeah, but why were you kidding

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ransom enters with two MPs.

Dialogue.Line: Going somewhere? Perhaps I can give you a lift?
General Smythe had made up his mind those people were guilty. He wanted that man to be shot!
Perhaps he knew they were guilty?
Oh, you don't really believe that?
No, I don't, but

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ransom enters.

Dialogue.Line: Well, we've got them. You'll never believe where we found them.
Where were they?
Well, I was on my way back here, I'd given up the search. It suddenly occurred to me I ought to go and tell Gorton about it.
Well, who's Gorton?
He's the Commandant at the prison. Popped into his office and there they were.
What were they doing there?

Do you know, that chap, he'd convinced old Gorton that he was a minister from Whitehall. And he'd nearly bluffed him into letting that Scots lad go. I don't know I must say I admire his gall. It seems a pity, really, to have to shoot him.
Sir, I'd like to speak to you, sir. The court martial wasn't in accordance with King's Regulations.
What?
I'm not satisfied.

Oh don't be ridiculous, man, it's perfectly fair. General's a great stickler for that kind of thing. Sentence will be carried out as soon as he returns. Lady Jennifer, notify Command Post, will you? Let them know the hunt's over.
Yes, certainly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ransom leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Do you see? He didn't remember what happened at the court martial.
He really seems to believe they had a fair trial!
The General wanted that man to be shot. Why?
I don't know. I think I'd better have a word with those civilians and try and find out. If Ransom comes back, keep him occupied, will you?
Right.
A redcoat, Jamie?
Aye, and he thinks he's in 1745.
But that's a complete anachronism.
Aye. It's a what?
It's something out of it's own time.
Yes, like the telecommunications unit in the General's room that I told you about.
Eh?
I found it when I was looking for the key.
Both these things are in the wrong time. But what are they doing here in 1917?
Shush.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs enters, revolver drawn.

Dialogue.Line: Close the door.
Yes Major, they were recaptured half an hour ago. Captain Ransom wanted me to let you know. Goodbye. I've notified all the command posts.
That's awfully kind of you. Has the General not returned yet?
No. Does he often disappear like this? I mean, surely he ought to keep you informed?
Well, he's a very busy man, you know. Where's young Carstairs?
Oh, he's gone to look for some transport.
Oh, good. I think I'd better go and make certain those prisoners are safely under lock and key.
It must be very difficult working for someone like General Smythe.
Yes, I suppose he is a bit of a martinet. He has a great deal of responsibility, you know.
Oh yes, but a great deal falls upon your shoulders, Captain.

Yes, I suppose it is a job, running a place like this you know. Quite a problem. People don't understand. It's the paperwork, you see. It's quite fantastic how many forms we have to fill in. Just look at that.
What is a video screen? Some kind of kinematograph?
Oh, well, it's a bit more complicated than that. If only I could show it to you.
If you'll take us to the General's room, we'll prove this thing exists!
All right, you show it to me and I'll believe you. But you'd better be right.
I see! But how do you keep a track of all the equipment?
Ah well, now that's the problem. I keep sending these subalterns the forms, and they just don't fill them in.
But if they're at the front, fighting?
There's no excuse for mislaying valuable military equipment. Do you know, in the last push we lost over one hundred shovels?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The telephone rings. Buckingham gets to it first.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, Lady Jennifer? Carstairs. Look, I. What, there with you now? Well, get rid of him, quickly!
Yes, all right. I will.
That for me?
Yes, all right.
Who was there?
The General.
The General?
He's at number seventeen command post and he'd like you to join him there immediately.

Oh, right. Well, what's he doing there? That's the farthest point of the sector! I'd better join him, I suppose. Jolly nice talking to you. You know, not many women take an interest in the problems of supply. Goodbye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ransom leaves. The telephone rings.

Dialogue.Line: Yes? Yes, he's just gone. Oh. All right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Buckingham goes to the window to watch a car drive away. Carstairs enters with the Doctor, Zoe and Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: What on earth are you doing?
There's no time to explain now. Now, where is this thing, Zoe?
It's over there.
But that's the General's private room!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Revolver still drawn, Carstairs leads the group in. Zoe opens the portrait door to reveal the monitor.

Dialogue.Line: There it is!
There's nothing there, only wall.
What? You mean you can't see that screen?
What are we supposed to be looking at?
Well, I still can't see anything.
Look at the wall! Concentrate!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs and Buckingham stare at the wood panelling until the dial and monitor appear.

Dialogue.Line: It is there. I can see it!
Can you see it yet?
Yes. But what's it for?
Well, it's like a telephone, only you can see people as well as hear them.
What's on the other end?
Good heavens, this thing is switched on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns it off, leaving Smythe and a man in a dark visor staring at a glass map.

Dialogue.Line: But we didn't see anything on the screen.
No, but somebody may have seen us. We've got to get away from here, all of us.
Get away? Where do you hope to get to?
Well, anywhere so long as it's away from here.
I just can't let you go, just like that.
Yes, you can. And you've got to come too. Your lives will be in danger now, both of you.
I think he's right.
Now look, my friends and I are leaving here. Are you going to shoot us down?
All right. I'll believe you.
I'll get the ambulance.
Yes. I'll meet you by the front entrance.
So what do you want us to do?
Just clamber into the ambulance and keep quiet. I'm going to have to bluff our way past the sentries. Now, just wait here. I'll get some maps.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Are we going back to the Tardis now?
No, no, no, no, we must stay here and see what is happening.
We can't leave these people now, anyway.
No, I suppose not.
Right, are you ready? Come on.
Carstairs, what's going on?
Orders from the General, sir. He wants the prisoners taken to HQ immediately.
Are you sure your message is genuine?
Well, yes, sir, I spoke to the General personally.
Well, I don't know. I had a message to meet him at command post seventeen. That was a fake.
Well, the General was most insistent, sir, but of course it is up to you, sir.
Oh, you'd better carry on.
Very good, sir. All right, move off. Any trouble mind, I won't hesitate to fire.
Just a minute, Carstairs.
Sir?
Where's Lady Jennifer?
She's somewhere around, sir.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs and the travellers leave.

Dialogue.Line: I want a word with her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The ambulance stops.

Dialogue.Line: Right, Zoe, up you go.
Okay, right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The SIDRAT has materialised in Smythe's room and the General has closed the portrait door properly.

Dialogue.Line: Where are the prisoners?
Everything's all right, sir. They're on their way to headquarters just as you ordered.
I gave no such order!
Well, they've just left with Lieutenant Carstairs, sir.
Ransom, you're a fool! Where's Lady Jennifer?
I don't know, sir. She gave me a message to meet you at command post seventeen. (looks out of the window) The ambulance, sir, it's gone.
Now we know what to look for. Well, issue a general order at once!
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Whilst the ambulance trundles along a road.

Dialogue.Line: Good, thank you. Ambulance spotted, sir.
Where?
Sector four, heading east, travelling very fast. I'll send out a motorcycle patrol.
No need for that.
Well, sector four could cut them off.
Concentration of artillery there. Yes, that should reach them.
We'll use artillery on an ambulance, sir?
That ambulance is in enemy hands, Ransom.
But there are two women on board.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe puts his spectacles on.

Dialogue.Line: I want a creeping barrage laid along that road. Do you understand? Do you understand?
Yes, I understand.
Good. Well, order the artillery to fire, then.
A very good idea, sir. Creeping barrage. Stop them dead.
That's just how we want them. Dead.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The shell explosions make the ambulance stop. Carstairs joins the Doctor, Jamie and Zoe in the back.

Dialogue.Line: Maps! Artillery barrage, and we're still seven miles from the German line.
Well, perhaps it's not, perhaps it's not German artillery.
Well, our chaps wouldn't fire at us.
No, but General Smythe might!
Whoever it is, his aim's getting better!
Let's get out of here! Bring the rest of the maps.
Righto! Stay here, keep under cover.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sits with Buckingham and Carstairs up front.

Dialogue.Line: Right!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The ambulance drives forward and fades to nothing.

Dialogue.Line: Oh!
What is it?
Fog. Can't see.
The mist, the gas!
Gas?
I can't go on, there's something stopping me.
It's not gas, go on.
I can't!
Well, move over. Let me, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gets behind the steering wheel and releases the handbrake.
The ambulance appears on a peaceful road winding besides a river - actually Seven Sisters Country Park, Sussex. They get out and look around.

Dialogue.Line: That's more like it.
That mist, Doctor, what was it?
I don't know, Zoe. Some sort of force field.
Where are we? There's no sign of the war here.
Yes, and the guns have stopped, too.
Yes. It's odd, Jamie.
Feeling better?
Yes. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Above the road and river. There's a vague sound of men shouting in the distance.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, that's better!
What's that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A phalanx of warriors are heading towards them lead by a two horse chariot. Romans!

Dialogue.Line: Oh, come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The ambulance engine catches and Carstairs gets in as Buckingham slowly backs the ambulance up the road and it fades away. When the Romans get there they just stop in mid yell.

Dialogue.Line: That was a close shave. Where are we, Doctor?
Oh no, we're not back here again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs and Buckingham join them in the back.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Lieutenant Carstairs, is this the only map you're supplied with?
Yes, that's the one.
It's a bit inadequate, isn't it?
Doctor, who were those people who attacked us just now?
Oh, they were Romans.
Oh, but that's impossible!
Oh, lots of impossible things happen when you pass through time.
Time? But no one can alter time.
Look, it is 1917 where we are now on this map. Where we were attacked by the Romans it is two thousand years ago.
But surely, Doctor
Surely before we met the Romans we passed through a mist didn't we? A gas you called it. Now, supposing this mist is a barrier between different time zones?
I see. So we went off the edge of this map and into a different time zone.
Yes. What we need is a map which covers all the time zones. I'm afraid we shall have to get back to General Smythe's headquarters, to the chateau.
Well how are we going to get back there?
Well, that's easy. You will take us!
No trace of them? Well, keep searching!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and the Doctor enter, followed by Carstairs.

Dialogue.Line: Lieutenant Carstairs reporting, sir. I brought back the prisoners.
Carstairs, what on earth have you been up to? And what do you mean by giving me that fake report from the General? I warn you, Carstairs, you're in very serious trouble! You're

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs points his revolver directly at Ransom.

Dialogue.Line: Have you gone mad?
I'm sorry about this, sir.
You'll be shot for this, Carstairs!
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie takes Ransom's gun.

Dialogue.Line: Don't do anything foolish, sir. I think it might be better if you raised your hands.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor rummages around for maps.

Dialogue.Line: Bandages, Doctor.
What? Oh, yes. I'm afraid that there's nothing here, only local maps. Here we are. Perhaps there's something in the General's room. I'll go and see.
This is mutiny. I hope you

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie stuffs a handkerchief into Ransom's mouth and fastens it there with a bandage.
The Doctor enters and looks around.

Dialogue.Line: Find anything?
Well, only this safe.
The only way to get inside that is to blow it up.
Oh, what a good idea.
You serious?
Well, this is a military establishment, there must be some explosives around here.
Right. I'll see what I can find.
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, I wonder whether perhaps I can pick this lock.
Aye, with a tuning fork?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: While Ransom is trussed up on the settee, Carstairs opens boxes and crates in the drawing room.

Dialogue.Line: Oh come on, Doctor, we haven't got all night. Someone's bound to turn up.
Yes, I know, Jamie. Oh dear, this is useless.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs enters with a hand-sized device.

Dialogue.Line: What's that thing?
It's a Mills bomb. It's all I could find. I thought we might hang it on the front of the safe and let it off.
Oh, well, yes, that might blow the room up very nicely, but I don't think it would affect the safe much. You see we have to concentrate the

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is fiddling with the primitive grenade.

Dialogue.Line: Look out!
Whole explosion into the lock there.
Blow us all up.
Now then, if I can pack the explosive into the lock and then detonate it. Ah, here we are. Now then. Ah yes, I see.
For goodness sake, be careful. That's Amatol in there.
It's all right. I do have the detonator, you know. Now then, just release this. There we are. Now what have we got? Oh yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pours the explosive powder onto a piece of paper.

Dialogue.Line: This fuse, how long does it last?
About four seconds.
Oh, that's not very good, is it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks for a longer fuse, briefly considering on of the tassels on Jamie's best sporran. He settles for breaking a candle and using its wick. He inserts it carefully into the safe lock.

Dialogue.Line: There we are.
Help! Help!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ransom has tipped over the settee and dislodged his gag, obviously.

Dialogue.Line: Sergeant Major! Help!
I'm sorry about this, sir. Can't have you making a row.
Hello.
Dropped my pen.
Ah. Captain Ransom about?
No, I'm looking after things. Can I help?
Well, it's a bit tricky, actually. The sentry found these two ladies hiding in an ambulance.
Well? What about it?
Well, you remember there was this spy flap earlier today. Something about them getting away in an ambulance and one of them was a woman. I don't think we've met before, have we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie strikes a match and they hide behind Smythe's camp bed. The Doctor covers his head with a pillow.

Dialogue.Line: Now we light the blue touch paper and retire immediately!
This is all completely ridiculous!
Really, old chap, you can leave them to me. I'm sure we can sort it out.
But don't you think I ought to wait for Captain Ransom?
He may be quite some time.
I can wait. How long do you say you've been on attachment here?
How long?
About three months.
Someone's out there with Carstairs.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go to listen at the door.

Dialogue.Line: You may leave them to me, old chap. It's quite under control.
Oh well, right you are. Sorry about all this. Do hope you understand. Can't afford to take chances, you see.
We quite understand.
Perhaps you could stay for dinner. We don't often see ladies here. The chaps in the mess would be delighted.
Sorry, but we really have to be on our way.
We shall have to put the fuse out. It's too late! Duck!
Cheerio!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Crane leaves. The safe goes Boom and he rushes back in again.

Dialogue.Line: What the blazes?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Crane runs in. The Doctor and Jamie are coughing. Crane turns then raises his arms.

Dialogue.Line: Now don't do anything foolish, old boy. Doc, have you got any more bandages?
Ah yes. Here we are, Jamie.
You're Carstairs, the one who went off with the spies!
Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie takes Crane out to be tied up. The Doctor has found a map marked off in triangles. Zoe enters.

Dialogue.Line: Look, Zoe. 1917 zone, Roman zone, American Civil War zone. This whole place is divided into time zones.
But there's a blank space in the middle. There's nothing marked at all.
Yes. Yes, and I think that that's where we've got to get to.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And not the Crimean, 30 Years, Russo-Japanese, Greek, Boer, Peninsular, English Civil or Mexican Civil war zones.
The ambulance is stopped by a German patrol.

Dialogue.Line: This is an ambulance. We have a seriously wounded officer in the back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A German goes round to see Carstairs having his brow mopped by Zoe, with Buckingham attending.

Dialogue.Line: Sie mũssen mit uns kommen.
Ah. You want me to come with you. Ah well, if you put it like that. Yes, here we go.
Well, what's going to happen to us?
Ah, foreigners! Look, what's the use of pretending that Carstairs is wounded? They're bound to find out sooner or later.
Well, at least it stopped them taking him to a prison camp. Besides, he's safe in the ambulance with Jennifer.
Aye, for how long though?
Well, perhaps the Doctor will be able to talk them into letting us go.
Aye.
For the last time, what is your name?
Why don't you just call me Doctor? LÜCKE: That is not a name. I want your full name.
Oh, very well. Doctor John Smith. LÜCKE: Good. Now we are getting somewhere. What are you doing behind our lines?
Well, we were lost, you see. LÜCKE: So, you are lost. And very conveniently you find your way through our lines.
I realise this must seem rather strange. LÜCKE: I find it both strange and suspicious.
But I can assure you we're quite harmless. LÜCKE: Three people dressed in civilian clothes trying to infiltrate through our lines. Admit it, you are spies.
No, no, no, we are not spies. LÜCKE: Then tell me where you came from before you were picked up by that ambulance.
Well, you see, that's rather difficult to explain. LÜCKE: Everything seems to be difficult for you to explain. I advise you to tell me the truth. Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lucke cocks his revolver.

Dialogue.Line: All right, if you insist.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A soldier gives them two Prussian helmets.

Dialogue.Line: Oh! I don't know how they stick it out here.
It's the same with the British, remember.
What a way to fight, though, hiding in wee holes and blasting each other with big guns.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Boom!

Dialogue.Line: Oh, I wish we could get out of here, Jamie!
Other planets? A time machine? The girl is from the future and the boy is from the past?
Well, you told me to tell you the truth. LÜCKE: I think you must be mad.
Why don't you ask my companions if you don't believe me? LÜCKE: Bringen Sie die anderen Engländer herein! Sofort! We shall soon see if your stories are the same.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Zoe enter.

Dialogue.Line: Young woman, where did you meet this man?
Tell him the truth, both of you. LÜCKE: Silence! Well?
We met at a space station. LÜCKE: A space station. And you, where did you meet this man?
In Scotland. LÜCKE: Ach, so. Now tell me, when?
In seventeen forty five. I was fighting the Redcoats. LÜCKE: You were fighting the Redcoats in seventeen forty five? That ambulance, was it going to a hospital or to a lunatic asylum?
Oh, dear. Look, look, I can prove to you that we come from another time. This is a sonic screwdriver. Now, where can I demonstrate? Ah, that revolver will do. It's all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lucke places his weapon on the table and the Doctor unscrews the hand grip without touching it.

Dialogue.Line: There we are. And back it goes. LÜCKE: Phantastisch!
Do you believe me now? LÜCKE: But it's impossible. You did not touch the screw. It just moved. Is it possible you are telling the truth?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A bald archetype Prussian enters, complete with duelling scar. All he needs is a monocle.

Dialogue.Line: Leutnant Lücke! LÜCKE: Jawohl, mein herr!
Wer sind diese Leute? LÜCKE: Wir haben hier
Was ist hier los? LÜCKE: Wir haben hier drei Englische zivilisten, herr Kapitän.
What are you doing here? Where do you come from?
Well LÜCKE: Er hat mir gesagt, dass er aus einem anderen Zeitalter kam, in annen rontschiff namen Tardis.
Time travellers?
Well, it is a little difficult to understand, but
Leutnant Lücke! Kommen sie bitte mit mir.
Jawohl, mein Kapitan.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Von Weich leads Lücke though a curtain and screws in his monocle.

Dialogue.Line: Es sind Englische spione! Wir müssen sie festhalten! Ich werde mit dem General darüber sprechen. LÜCKE: Jawohl herr Kapitän Von Weich.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lücke walks slowly back through the curtain.

Dialogue.Line: You are dangerous English spies.
But this is ridiculous. LÜCKE: You are spies! And you are going to be shot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Behind a portrait hanging on a panelled wall is another monitor screen, just like Smythes'.

Dialogue.Line: Von Weich, 1917 German front line to central control. We have captured three people who escaped from the British sector. They claim to be time travellers.
No, no, no! We are not spies! The sonic screwdriver. We've just shown you with the gun. LÜCKE: Yes. You did something with thee gun.
Let the Doctor show you again, eh?
Yes, Jamie. Now, it's very simple. Put the gun on the table. You can keep your hand on it again if you like! Now, watch.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The screw in the grip goes up and down.

Dialogue.Line: Yes! And then you put it back again!
That's right. LÜCKE: Is it possible?
Oh, we've got lots of tricks like that. Let me show you. Catch, Jamie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie catches the gun and points it at Lucke.

Dialogue.Line: Now then, Lieutenant. I'm sorry about this, but perhaps you'd be good enough to take us back to our ambulance!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Large and alien, staffed by people wearing visors and overalls. An alarm sounds. Smythe is also there. Four guards in wet suits with laser rifles or similar enter, followed by a man with a square medallion around his neck. Smythe gestures the other staff to leave.

Dialogue.Line: Did you have a comfortable trip, sir?
Excellent. The War Lord is pleased with our work. But the rate of progress must be accelerated.

A report from my zone, sir. The prisoners that escaped from the chateau been recaptured in the German lines. I have advised they be shot immediately. They gave some ridiculous story about being time travellers.
Time travellers? And you ordered them to be shot? I want them brought here for re-interrogation.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The alarm sounds again.

Dialogue.Line: Those prisoners, they've escaped. They will probably go back to your lines.
How did that happen? VON WEICH [on monitor]: They tricked my human Lieutenant.
Oh that is sheer incompetence!
They also escaped from you, General Smythe. Organise pursuit and report back here. VON WEICH [on monitor]: Sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ends.

Dialogue.Line: Issue a general alert. But I want these people captured alive.

General alert to all time zones. Five escaped prisoners travelling in a 1917 British Army ambulance clearly marked with a red cross. These prisoners may be capable of crossing the time zone barriers. Officers are to describe the ambulance to their human troops as a hostile vehicle which much be destroyed at all costs!
Time travellers? I wonder.
The description of the prisoners is as follows.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Under the gaze of an American soldier, the ambulance stops and Carstairs goes to the back.

Dialogue.Line: Can I have a look at that map, Doctor?
Yes. Here we are.
We've just been through another one of those mists and we've gone off the edge of my map.
Where do you think we are, Doctor?
I think we're right about there.
America 1862. That was the American Civil War wasn't it? Another war!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gun shots.

Dialogue.Line: Get down!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The soldier fires, and Carstairs shoots back.

Dialogue.Line: Get moving!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pokes his head out.

Dialogue.Line: Oh Doctor, be careful!
Zoe, we're right. That was an American Civil War soldier.
You mean we're mixed up in another war now?
Yes. But it means we're on the right road, and we're still making for that blank space in the middle of the map.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Further on, a tree falls in front of the ambulance.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie, the Doctor and Zoe get out of the ambulance. They are about to move the tree when shots are fired. Carstairs is the only one who actually hits his targets though. The survivors run away.

Dialogue.Line: Get that tree moved!
Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs takes out another man creeping up behind the ambulance, and tackles a fourth hand to hand. Jamie deals with another as the Doctor and Zoe drag the tree off the road.

Dialogue.Line: Where have you been? We've done it without you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs hold off some horsemen as the three get back into the ambulance. Then he has to change pistols as more cavalry arrive.

Dialogue.Line: Lady Jennifer! Drive on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Further on, Buckingham pulls the ambulance over in some bushes and cavalry ride past. She opens the engine cover.

Dialogue.Line: What's wrong?
Afraid we've run out of petrol.
Oh no!
Where's Lieutenant Carstairs?
He held them off while we got away.
Oh, dear.
Oh, well now what do we do?
There's only one thing for it. We shall have to go on by foot. Come along.
If my troops make a push here, what resistance can you put up?
Along here we shall have pillboxes, machine gun nests, landmines. You'll have no chance, but it will be an excellent test of the morale of your humans. Your entire force will be wiped out.
Ah, but I will use my reinforcements to turn your flank. There!
Then it will not be a fair battle.
Perhaps not, but it will be an excellent test of your morale.
Those specimens we were discussing. An ambush was laid but only one was captured.
Which one?
A young Lieutenant, one of yours. He could have got away, but he stayed behind to help the others escape.
These humans are very loyal to one another in stress situations.
One of their finest qualities. He's being brought back here for re- processing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Buckingham are stranded in the American Civil War zone. A group of soldiers surround them.

Dialogue.Line: And just who might you be?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Very large inside, with transparent room dividers.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, look, it is like the Tardis. Bigger inside than out.

Should you arrive on another planet, you may not be aware that the problem is to retain the specimen's personality as a fighting man while at the same time putting him under our control. As you know, we remove the human specimens from their own world and time, and place them in a context which seems to them to be the same. It is vital that they continue to believe that they are living their own lives on the planet Earth and fighting the wars from which they were taken. ZOE [sotto) : So this isn't Earth.
Quite right, Zoe, quite right.

With the majority of human specimens, the process used is both lasting and effective. However, in the case of certain humans of particularly strong character and individuality, the effects of the process have not been permanent. Gradually the processing tended to fade and the specimens developed the ability to pass through the Time Zone Barriers. Some formed themselves into resistance groups which have considerably hampered the progress of our plan. It is to overcome this problem that I have further refined our processing technique. To demonstrate the process I chosen a particularly difficult specimen. A man who finally shook off the effects of the process completely, and allied himself to resistance elements in order to fight us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Guards bring out a gurney on which Carstairs is strapped.

Dialogue.Line: This Lieutenant Carstairs is a 1917 British army officer, who for some time after his initial processing, believed himself to be fighting for his country. There would be no need for security. When I came to your people I was promised efficiency and cooperation. Without the knowledge I have, this complete venture would be impossible.
We have given you every facility. If you have complaints I suggest you take them to the War Lord.
I intend to do so. And now I suggest you finish the interrogation of that girl before she escapes as well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Security Chief enters. He picks up the guard.

Dialogue.Line: Where is the girl? You fool, where is she?!
Do you not see, though? This thing could take us all back to the place where it's controlled from!
How do you know?
Oh, where do you think those two came from?
Well, is it true? Answer me.
Do you think I'd help you?
You'll do as you're told. Take those two away.
Now look, you want to find out what's going on, don't you? Och, I can't wait for you to make up your mind!
Oh, wait for me.
Ah, now, Lady Jennifer, I don't think you should come.
Because I'm a woman?
No, er, well, in a way, yes.
That settles it then. I'm certainly coming. You can't go alone.
No, you're right, miss, he can't. I'm going with him. But you're staying here.
Oh now, look here!
You're a nurse, you said?
Yes, but what's that got to do with it?
I've got hundreds of injured men back at my headquarters. They need the help of someone like you.
Yes, I suppose you're right. Tell Lieutenant Carstairs that. Well, tell him I'll see him when you all get back.
Right.
Good luck.
Oh, thank you.
Take her back to our headquarters. Thank you, Miss.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Buckingham leaves. Russell goes over to Von Weich.

Dialogue.Line: You. Guard him. If he gives you any trouble, shoot him. You two, you're coming with me. Come on, move!
Door's closing!
Quick! Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Security Chief releases the Scientist from the brain-washing machine.

Dialogue.Line: What happened?
That young officer got away.
How?
Oh, the one in the lecture who asked all the questions, he tricked me. I must report this to the War Chief.
No! You two, wait outside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards leave.

Dialogue.Line: But he must be informed.
These people are no ordinary resistance group. The girl said they have the secret of space time travel.
That's impossible.
She was under the truth machine.
But the War Chief. He's the only one who understands space time travel.
And his people.
What are you suggesting?
He is not one of our race. Who knows where his true loyalties lie?
But he came to us of his own accord.
He is a traitor to his own people. How can we be sure he is not a traitor to us?
Transportation returning from the American Civil War Zone, sir.
Good.
But they're not following the routine, sir. They haven't called in.
Have you tried to make contact?
Yes, sir.
All right, inform the Security Chief. No! No, I'll handle this myself. This is the War Chief to Security section. All guards to landing bay. The following procedure will be carried out
Oh Jamie! Doctor, we've got to help them!
No, there's nothing we can do.
We must get away from here.
But we can't. Jamie. We can't.
Do you want us all to get killed? Go on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards drag their victims away.

Dialogue.Line: Oh Doctor, what about Jamie? Have they killed him?
I don't know!
Let's go this way.
No, no, this way to the processing room.
Why do you want to go to the processing room?
Don't ask questions, just follow me.
Oh!
I believe that amongst this resistance group that attacked the base are people who have arrived on this planet without being brought here by us.
That's impossible!
Is it? What about the girl Zoe, and this man the Doctor she spoke of? She said he had a space time travel machine.
Yes I know, but
Have we taken humans from later than the Earth year 1917?
Of course not. Greater technological knowledge would be dangerous.
Yet this man who tricked you had sufficient technological knowledge to understand the mental processing machinery.
Yes, that's true. But how could these people get here?
The War Chief. His people have the secret of time travel.
Are you suggesting he's bringing in his own people, the Time Lords?
He came to us because he wanted power. Perhaps there are others of his people who feel the same.
Can you prove this? If so, you must tell the War Lord immediately.
Unfortunately I have no proof. You must help me find proof. I insist. This is a matter of security.
All right, what do you want me to do?
These resistance people. Before you reprocess them, study them carefully. If you find anything unusual send the prisoner concerned to me for questioning.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There are guards near the Processing room.

Dialogue.Line: We've got to get in there.
Why?
Now that room, the other side. That must've been next door. Yes, come on.
Now what's he up to?
I've no idea, but I think we'd better follow. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Zoe and Carstairs push their way through hanging racks of greatcoats, to the wall adjoining the processing room.

Dialogue.Line: Some sort of preformed plastic, wouldn't you say, Zoe?
Yes, but why are you so interested in it, Doctor?

Little bits of metal imbedded in it. Yes, I think these panels must be held together by some kind of magnetic forcefield. Now if I could reverse that field. Cut me off some pieces of tape, will you please, Zoe?
Oh yes.
That's right. One there, that's right. And one just there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tapes pieces of wire over the curves in the plastic panel.
Jamie, Russell and other soldiers lie in a heap in the corner while the Scientist uses his helmet device to view another man's brain.

Dialogue.Line: All right, take him away.
Doctor, what on Earth are you doing?
Well, it's no secret, boy, it's simply a case of reversing the magnetic field of this panel.
Doctor, why don't you use your sonic screwdriver as a power source?
What a good idea, yes.
There's just one thing though.
Yes?
All these panels are interlinked.
Yes, well?
Well, if you take one away what's to stop all the rest down like a pack of cards?
Well, we'll just have to take that risk, won't we? Now then, stand well clear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor attaches his sonic screwdriver to one end of the final long wire linking all the rest. The panel glows briefly.

Dialogue.Line: Nothing's happened.
Watch.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gently removes the panel and sets it down so they look in through a gap over the top. Jamie is being placed on the examination table.

Dialogue.Line: It's Jamie! He's alive!
I hoped he might be.
But how? They shot him down.
Well, the guns they use can be adjusted. I think he was just stunned.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Scientist stares into Jamie's brain and sees a regular pattern of oblongs instead of a swirly brain-like one.

Dialogue.Line: He was right. Take this prisoner to the Security Chief for questioning.
Doctor, why are they taking him away?
I think they've possibly discovered that he was never processed.
We'd better get him out of there, then.
No, no, wait.
Have you started the reprocessing yet?
No, I've just been carrying out the preliminary examinations.
Why? Why not just reprocess them?
I, well, these people have shown considerable courage and enterprise. They may make future leaders.
Where is this prisoner being taken?
Oh, the Security Chief. He wants to question one of them before reprocessing.
Really? Why this one in particular?
Oh, he just seemed to be the most suitable.
For what reason? For what reason!
His brain patterns are different.
Different how?
Well, he appears not to have been processed before.
Really? How interesting. All right, carry on. (The guards carry Jamie away.)
But in future inform me of all such unusual developments.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Prepare the reprocessing machine. We shall begin with this one.
Oh Doctor, we're too late. Where have they taken him?
I don't know, but don't worry, at least we know that he's alive. Now then, we've got to get in there. Lieutenant?
Right, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: While the Scientist adjusts his brain-washing machine, Carstairs goes through the hole in the wall and grabs the scientist's assistant. He bundles him unceremoniously back into the clothing store.

Dialogue.Line: I think you'll find that bit goes there.
Ah, thank you!
How long do you intend keeping me here?
Until they come back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: David Troughton, Patrick's son.

Dialogue.Line: And supposing they don't come back?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Von Weich stands.

Dialogue.Line: I'd like some water.
All right. Sit down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Trying to keep his rifle aimed at Von Weich all the time, Moor sidles towards a canteen. As soon as he looks away, Von Weich tries to go for the communications device.

Dialogue.Line: Stop! Try that again and I'll kill you.
But who sent you here?
Nobody sent us. I came with the Doctor.
Why did he decide to come to this planet?
He didn't. It was an accident.
Accident? Explain.
It's the Tardis, you see. He can't control it. We just arrived here.
Was the Doctor summoned here by one of us?
No, we just arrived.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief and a guard enter.

Dialogue.Line: Don't let me interrupt you.
The questioning is over.
What have you learnt?
Nothing of importance.
Really? Will you be questioning the others?
They are all from the same resistance group. They will all tell the same story.
But this one is different, surely?
Why should he be?
This one hasn't been processed before, has he?
It's possible.
It's a fact! Why was I not informed?
This is a matter of security. Security is my responsibility, as you often remind me.
Your first responsibility is to me.
No! My first responsibility is to the War Lord and to my people.
You don't trust me. But if you question my loyalty, tell the War Lord. But I warn you, be absolutely sure of your suspicions because if you accuse me without positive proof, I shall crush you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is using his smelling salts on Russell while Carstairs reloads his revolver.

Dialogue.Line: Can't you hurry it up?
What happened? Where am I?
It's all right. You're quite safe.
Who are you?
We're your friends.
You'll have to hurry it up, Doctor.
Doctor? You must be the one that Jamie was talking about. Where is he?
Well, I'm afraid that they've taken him away. Now, up you get.
Doctor, we're wasting time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard comes past the open door to the central area and Carstairs shoots him.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, Doctor, we must get out of here!
Quickly through the gap in the wall here, Zoe, help him.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tries to take the brain washing machine off its stand.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, Doctor.
I'll be a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The alarm sounds. Carstairs shoots at another guard outside.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, Doctor!
Just a minute!
No, now. or we'll all be caught! Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor abandons the machine.
Carstairs and the Doctor replace the wall panel.

Dialogue.Line: What is this place?
Well, it's the headquarters of the people who are running this whole disgraceful business.
Just the people I want to get my hands on.
Yes, it's not quite as simple as that. There are rather a lot of them.
I don't care how many of them there are!
They have rather sophisticated weapons. You wouldn't stand a chance.
Oh. So what do we do now?
We're going to return to the time zones and organise the resistance into one big army!
If you can find them. They're spread all over the place. I've been trying to link them up myself, but it's finding them and you don't know who you can trust.
Ah yes, we do now. My friend Zoe has memorised an entire list of the resistance and their whereabouts.
Yes, I memorised the files when I was in the security room.
Now I must get you all back to the landing bay.
Those guards'll be all over the place.
Yes, what we need is some kind of disguise.
British Private, aren't you? 19th century.
You can see that, can't you.
Oh would you mind reaching my monocle for me? It's in my pocket there. Thank you.
Now sit down again.
Don't you talk to me like that. I'm a British Officer!
No, you're not. You're my prisoner.
I'm not your prisoner, Moor. I'm your commanding Officer. Do you understand?
I'm not, I'm not in the army. The resistance I'm in!
You're in the British army, Private Moor, the year is 1871. You're in the British army, and I'm your commanding Officer. Now, untie me.
(to War Chief) They are in here, trapped. (to guards) Right, in!
They were seen here by my men.
Where are they now, vanished into thin air?
There is only one way they could have escaped. By use of a space time machine.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief goes across to the far wall and pushes at several panels.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry to crush your wild theories.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He pushes the loose panel.

Dialogue.Line: There's your space time machine.
After them!
You're too late for that. They will be on their way to the landing bay by now, I should imagine. Try and get there before them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie wakes to see a figure in a greatcoat and gas mask.

Dialogue.Line: Ah!
It's all right, Jamie, it's me.
Oh.
All right, put on this great coat.
Where's Zoe? What's happened?
She's waiting outside. Now come along.
Fall in by twos. Come along, hurry up. There's no time to be lost.
Zoe.
Are you ready? Right. Quick march!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two soldiers grab the technician and drag him away.

Dialogue.Line: Are you sure you can work these controls, Doctor?
Yes, I think so, Zoe. Now let me see.
There are more guards!
Oh my goodness!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor moves some control rods and sets up a protective force field.

Dialogue.Line: There, that should stop them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Russell and Carstairs deal with the two that got through with help from Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie! All right! Now, I'll preset it for the 1917 zone, and off we go.
Doctor, how did you do it so easily?
It's not very difficult, Zoe. Now the doors.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A SIDRAT open.

Dialogue.Line: Come along. Don't be afraid, you've gone before.
After you, Doctor.
No, no, I shall follow in a few moments.
You mean you're staying here?
No, but I must get the processing machine.
Ah, if you're staying, I'd better stay too.
You can count on me then, Doctor.
Oh, very well. Go on, Zoe, off you go. We'll follow in a few minutes. Good luck.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe, Russell and the soldiers go into the SIDRAT and the Doctor dematerialises it remotely.

Dialogue.Line: What are you going to do about those guards, Doctor?
We're going to let them in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards run into an empty bay, then out again.

Dialogue.Line: You understand now, Moor? I am your commanding Officer.
You, you are my Commanding Officer. Yes, sir.
Good, good. Now, Moor, give me your gun.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As Moor is about to hand it over, the SIDRAT materialises and Russell steps out.

Dialogue.Line: Moor, shoot them! That's an order!
Back in there, quick. Moor? Moor, it's me, Russell.
Private Moor, shoot him.
Don't take any notice of him, Moor. You're one of us, one of the resistance, remember?
Resistance? No, I'm in the army. Oh oh two three nine Moor. Private Moor.
Shoot him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Russell reaches out, grabs Moor's rifle barrel and disarms him. The two men struggle and Moor gets Russell's service revolver from its holster. Russell forces him to drop it and they continue fighting until Moor is knocked out.

Dialogue.Line: Stay.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Von Weich picks up the revolver.

Dialogue.Line: You come one step nearer you'll die. Good. Now you're both coming back with me. Get inside the machine.
No, you'll have to shoot me first.
Very well, if you prefer to die that's your affair!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gunshot! Von Weich falls to the ground with a bullet from Moor's rifle inside him.

Dialogue.Line: I had to shoot him, didn't I?
Thank goodness you did, lad.
I'm not sure what happened.
You've just saved our lives, that's what happened.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: While Jamie helps the Doctor get the brain wash machine.

Dialogue.Line: So you have lost them. They have got away.
One of them knew how to operate our space time machines.
Are you blaming me for that?
You knew they would head for the landing bay. You knew one of them could operate our machines.
Of course. That is, after all, how they got here. Logic seems to be your weak point. Do something about this resistance group before the War Lord arrives.
Wherever they are, I shall find them.
Is this all right, Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie holds out a knapsack.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, Jamie, that's splendid. Put it in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts the machine into it.

Dialogue.Line: There we are. That's it, right. Come on, off we go. Just a minute. Hold that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hands the sack to Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: Now what?
What are those, Doctor?
They're gas filled valves. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They run out of the room and the Scientist sneaks in.

Wearing the gas mask, the Doctor throws one the gas filled valves onto the landing bay floor. The technicians and guards collapse, and the Doctor manipulates the controls to open a SIDRAT. They rush in and it dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: Did we get away all right?
Yes I hope so, Jamie. There we go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sound suddenly stops.

Dialogue.Line: But, they must have stopped it from the outside.
Well can they get in the doors?
No, not now. I've set the emergency lock.
Will we still get away all right?
Yes, it's only a question of overriding the master control. Now, it's a slightly different design to the Tardis.
Open the doors and surrender. You are trapped.
There is no chance of escape! Surrender and we will spare your lives.
What are you going to do, Doctor?
Don't worry. These things are impregnable against outside attack.
You mean like the Tardis?
This is your last chance. Surrender now!
How do you propose to get them out?
We will wait. They will come out.
No, we won't wait. We'll force them out.
What do you intend to do?
Activate the dimensional control.
Are we doing all right, Doctor?
Very nicely, Jamie. Now, don't worry. Nothing can happen to us in here.
Am I seeing things? The walls! Look!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The walls are getting closer.

Dialogue.Line: And the ceiling too!
Oh, what have they done?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The ceiling drops, forcing the Doctor, Carstairs and Jamie to their knees.

Dialogue.Line: You must surrender, Doctor, or you will all be crushed to death. You have thirty seconds to decide.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The inside is now barely big enough to hold the three men.

Dialogue.Line: Thirty seconds before you are crushed to death.
What are we going to do, Doctor?
We've got no choice. We have to do what they say.
Twenty seconds!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief moves more controls on the panel.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing now?
Reducing the dimensions further.
Wait!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The SIDRAT opens and the Doctor crawls out waving a white handkerchief.

Dialogue.Line: Bring out the others.
What are you going to do with us?
Bring out the others!
I won't have my friends ill-treated, you know.
You are in no position to make terms.
I am here under a flag of truce. I demand to know what you are going to do with us.
For the last time, tell your friends to come out. Or would you sooner they were crushed to death?
Oh, I think that that's a perfectly horrid idea.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor throws down his last gas-filled diode.

Dialogue.Line: Guards, stop him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: While everyone else is choking on the gas, the Doctor has his handkerchief over his mouth, dashes to the control panel, sets the dimension controls back to normal and removes other control symbols before running back into the SIDRAT and closing its door.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, well done, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The SIDRAT dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: Can't you stop them?
He's locked off the controls and taken the master circuit rods. What an ingenious fellow he is.
His ingenuity could ruin everything. Alert all time zones!
I suggest we pay particular attention to the 1917 zone.
Is that where they are going?
I can't tell for sure. These master circuit rods could guide the machine to any one of the time zones.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts the new control symbols on the panel by the door.

Dialogue.Line: Well, where are we going, Doctor?
Anywhere but the 1917 zone, Jamie.
Are we not going back to Zoe and the Tardis?
Yes, eventually, but not just now. That's where they'll be looking for us.
What are we going to do then, Doctor?
Well, we'll go into one of the nearby zones and cross the time zone barrier on foot. Oh! Ah, yes, here we are. (A final symbol goes on the panel.)
Haven't you traced them yet?
It's impossible to pick them up when the SIDRAT is still moving. I'll pinpoint their position the moment it lands.
All time zones are ready to hunt them down as soon as you provide the necessary information.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An alarm sounds.
