Dialogue.Line: The War Lord is arriving from the home planet.
He's chosen rather an inconvenient time.
I shall go and receive him.
No, I'll receive him. You stay here and supervise the capture of that resistance group.
The war Lord will expect me!
The War Lord will expect everything to be running smoothly and under control, which, at the moment it isn't.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Keep your eyes on the operations maps! I want to know the moment that capsule arrives in a time zone.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mealtime for a change. Carstairs and Jamie are eating apples.

Dialogue.Line: Its taking its time, isn't it?
Yes, Jamie. I probably confused the controls readjusting them in space, in
You've no idea which zone we're going to land in, Doctor?
Well, no, not really, no.
Oh, just like the Tardis, eh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The SIDRAT rematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, here we go. Help me on with the processing machine. Now remember, as soon as we land we must make ourselves scarce.
Eh?
Well they're bound to be on the alert for us.
Alert the Roman zone commanders in sector five. Transmit map references and order troops to surround the area. These resistance people must be captured or destroyed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A technician leaves. A man in black with the War Chief and an armed guard has arrived.

Dialogue.Line: So my information is correct. I've heard disquieting rumours of serious trouble here. Are they true?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Philip Madoc is back.

Dialogue.Line: There have been temporary difficulties.
But they have been overcome?
Almost.
War Chief. The defective processing machinery, has it been rectified?
Your scientists did get effective machines, but
But what?
Unfortunately, it was removed by an intruding party of resistance men.
They penetrated the control area? They just walked in? How?
I have the situation under control, War Lord. It is only a matter of time before they are recaptured.
Then I hope that time is on your side.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A technician brings a report to the Security Chief.

Dialogue.Line: Report from the Roman zone.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs is looking at a map as they walk.

Dialogue.Line: Are you sure this is the right way, sir?
Well, I don't know. It's rather difficult to tell, isn't it.
I think it is, Doctor. I seem to remember that hill.
Isn't this where we were attacked by the Romans?
Huh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And here they come again, charging along the ridge.

Dialogue.Line: Come on! Back to the time zone barrier!
They're escaping again. Moving back to the time zone barrier. Our processed Roman legions won't be able to follow them there.
Then we will send in my security guards from the control centre.
No, not again. We are carrying out a delicately controlled operation. The presence of guards in the time zones could stretch he credulity of the processed humans. It would be most dangerous.
It will be even more dangerous if we allow this Doctor to remain alive.
Have you looked for this space time machine of theirs?
What use is that to us?
They will no doubt try to return to it. That's where we should be looking for them. It's a simple enough conclusion. You might even have reached it yourself.
I have reached a number of conclusions about you and about this man, the Doctor.
Indeed? Then perhaps you'd like to share them with us?
This Doctor arrived here on this planet we have chosen for the war games. He brought with him companions who have not been subjected to our mental processing.
A fact you tried to conceal.
They came in a space time machine. The secret of space time travel is known only to you and to your people.
And I brought that secret here.
You have shown us how to operate these machines, but not how to construct them. These people were summoned by one who is in league with his own kind, plotting to betray us!
You cannot produce one single atom of proof!
The accumulation of evidence is overwhelming!
That's enough! That's enough from both of you. Now, I am tired of this eternal bickering. Your inability to work together is endangering our whole plan. You have a choice. Co-operate or be replaced.
Are we safe in here, Doctor?
Yes, yes, they can't follow us into a time zone barrier. Oh, Lieutenant Carstairs, do you feel all right?
Perfectly, why?
Oh, good. That means the processing machine is working all right.
Oh, where do we go from now, Doctor?
Just follow me, Jamie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The three men arrive to the sound of distant warfare. A man in a small weapons emplacement gets on his field telephone.
The Sergeant Major takes the call.

Dialogue.Line: I'll tell General Smythe immediately, sir. Excuse me, sir.
What is it?
Report from number three observation point, sir. Three persons spotted answering to the descriptions of the two spies and the officer wanted for desertion, sir.
Map?
They'd be just about, er, here, sir.
How very convenient. Right next to a machine gun emplacement.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Jamie and Carstairs run down the muddy bank near the machine gun. The Doctor falls.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The machine gun fires.

Dialogue.Line: Take cover! They've got us pinned down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: To the rear of the machine gunners are Zoe and two resistance fighters. They knock out the gunners with their musket butts. The Doctor, Jamie and Carstairs have been surrounded by British troops.

Dialogue.Line: No, don't shoot. You'll hit my friends. We'll follow them.
You've caused me a great deal of trouble.
Good, I'm very glad to hear it. I suppose you're going to subject us to another one of your farcical courts martial?
In your case, that won't be necessary. You have already been condemned to death.
And what about my friends?
They will be given the chance to redeem themselves, in the most dangerous sector of the front line.
After some more of your mental processing, I suppose?
They will have the opportunity of making the supreme sacrifice for their King and country.
You can drop all that nonsense. We know what's going on.
Do you, Carstairs?
Yes. This isn't the war. We're not even on our own planet. Do you realise that, Sergeant Major? This General of yours isn't even a human being.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe puts on his spectacles.

Dialogue.Line: The prisoner is delirious, Sergeant Major. He's talking nonsense.
Yes, sir, delirious, sir. Talking nonsense, sir.
Listen to me, Sergeant Major!
It's no use, Carstairs. Nothing you say will have any effect. Sergeant Major, prepare a firing squad.
Sir!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Burns leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Do you have the authority to have me killed?
I don't need any authority.
Your alien superiors will want to question me.
You've caused me a great deal of trouble and embarrassment. Now, I'm afraid, you're going to pay for it with your life!
So you're simply being malicious!
Revenge can be very satisfying.
Firing party ready, sir!
Take him away!
Look, leave him alone!
Come along!
Keep these other two here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe reports in on the video link.

Dialogue.Line: Smythe, 1917 zone. I have recaptured three of the escaped prisoners.
Excellent!
I want them sent here immediately. SMYTHE [on monitor]: Unfortunately one of them is already dead.
Which one? SMYTHE [on monitor]: The one that calls himself the Doctor. He was shot trying to escape.
Did you recover the machine? SMYTHE [on monitor]: Machine?
Didn't you receive your instructions? They took with them the new processing machine. It must be recovered! SMYTHE [on monitor]: Yes, of course I will.
Don't fail us, Smythe. The War Lord is here and he doesn't like failures.
(sotto) We've got to try and save the Doctor.
(sotto) I wouldn't get anywhere near him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe enters.

Dialogue.Line: (sotto) How about if I
(sotto) Quiet.
That machine you took, where is it? Where is it?!
The Doctor's got it.
Firing squad, attention! Load!
Only the Doctor knows where it is. You kill him, you'll never get it back.
Squad, aim. Squad
Stop!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gunfire outside.

Dialogue.Line: Jesus!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe draws his revolver and goes to the door. He fires as the long barrel of a musket appears. With another expletive he goes into his room. Jamie and Carstairs disarm their captors as more resistance fighters enter.

Dialogue.Line: Russell! The Doctor, what happened to him?
I don't know. We've just attacked the front of the building.
Doctor! I thought they'd shot you!
Fortunately, Zoe arrived in time. Where's General Smythe?
He's in there.
What? But he'll be calling for help. You've got to stop him!
Quick, lads. Over here!
It's the resistance. They're attacking in force. You must send help! WAR CHIEF [on monitor: Did you recover the machine?
I haven't had a chance. You must send help! WAR CHIEF [on monitor]: New master circuit rods for the travel machines are being prepared.
You must send help now! WAR CHIEF [on monitor]: Smythe, deactivate the area control.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The fighters have failed to break down the door to Smythe's room.

Dialogue.Line: Right lads, stand back.
Deactivate the area control. Deactivate the area control. Deactivate the area control!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smythe removes the cover from the fireplace to reveal a computer. He is just about to pull out some units when Russell bursts in. They exchange shots and Smythe dies.

Dialogue.Line: Quick, Doctor, in here. Look. I think he was trying to destroy it.
Why would he want to do that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe turns off the monitor.

Dialogue.Line: They have taken over the Chateau.
And the Doctor is still alive. Smythe was a fool. He deserved to die.
The Doctor has the processing machine. Does he have the knowledge and the ability to use it?
Yes. I think he has.
Then the situation's urgent, isn't it? Fortunately, they're in a very vulnerable position now. If they've made a mass attack then all their forces are concentrated in one position, the chateau.
This time we must use the guards.
No, we will invalidate the experiment. If they are concentrated in this one place, it would be simple enough to wipe them out with an artillery barrage.

Simple, but just as foolish as using the security guards. A violent attack on the Chateau would almost certainly destroy the control units there. The time zone barriers would disappear. No, use the conventional forces. Could be quite amusing. A mass attack on the chateau. A pincer movement with our little band of heroes caught in it's jaws.
What do you make of it, Doctor?
I'm not sure, Zoe. I think they've got something to do with the time zone barriers.
Doctor?
Huh?
There's troops moving in from all sides.
Oh no! Ohm my word, How many resistance did you bring?
Well, not enough to stand up against an army. Hadn't we better try and get away?
Look, it's too late for that. We're surrounded.
We could try and break out through here. Some of us might get away.
Not a chance. We'd be caught between two armies.
Yeah.
Mister Russell, how long can you hold on here?
Well, not long, Doctor. Our forward position's about to fall back already.
Well, you must hold on as long as you can. I think I've got the answer. You see, we have to have a safe base from which to fight these people. I must go and get on with my work.
What does he mean? What's he up to?
I don't know, But we'll do as he says and stick it out here for as long as we can.
That won't be long, sir. Listen to that lot.
Yeah.
Give some help, Zoe. I want to dismantle this.
What for?
To find out how it works, of course. Don't ask questions, just do what I say.
Well, what can I do?
You go and ask. You go and help Mister Russell.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Now then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor removes a circuit pack and starts to take it apart with sonic screwdriver.

Dialogue.Line: British troops are advancing from here and here, converging with French troops advancing from here. Germans are advancing from this side together with the Austro-Hungarians.
It is taking longer than it should. These resistance people are putting up a good fight.
They will be crushed.
They have escaped before. They could do it again.
Not this time. I am in control.
And the Doctor? Will he die with the rest?
Why shouldn't he?
He seems to have a charmed life.
Only when you have a hand in his fate. This Doctor will die.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Behind a barricade of furniture, the resistance are exchanging fire with the troops outside.

Dialogue.Line: It's no good.
This is only the vanguard. We know there's more of them to come. Grenade!
Look out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Russell pulls the French soldier into the room through the French windows. Jamie throws the grenade back outside.

Dialogue.Line: Duck!
It's no good, Russell. We must get away from here.
Doctor, you and Zoe must try and get away from here.
No, I don't think that will be necessary.
But Doctor
Shall we try it, Zoe? Right, here we go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns a knob at the bottom of the computer.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, now what?
Shush! Listen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: No more gunfire.

Dialogue.Line: Stopped. It's stopped.
Not a sound.
Some sort of trick.
No, Mister Russell, look out of the window.
Aye, a mist.
Yes. I've set up a time zone barrier all round the chateau.
So none of the processed people will be able to get at us.
Exactly, but your people can come and go just as you please. At last we've got a safe base from which to fight them! We can carry out the next step in complete safety.
What next step, Doctor?
Is this one of yours, Mister Russell?
No, Doctor. I pulled him through the window.
He's just the man we need.
So much for your armies of processed humans.
Smythe should have destroyed the machine.
We should have sent in my security guards.
And ruin the entire experiment?

The Security Chief is right. You have failed. And your leadership of the security forces has hardly been spectacularly successful. I will take charge of the whole situation. Now listen carefully, this is what I plan to do.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The SIDRAT materialises and a guard, the Security Chief carrying the machine, and the Doctor comes out to face a phalanx of armed guards.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, don't worry, I'm not going to hurt you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is taken away.

Dialogue.Line: We should have been prepared for it.
It's no good talking about what we should have done. Zoe, can you work that stuff and get another one of those things to arrive here?
Not on your life! You call one of those things, it'll be full of guards. They may have sent one anyway.
Sergeant? You got any explosives?
Lots of dynamite, sir.
Right, we'll put some here, where the thing lands.
But if you blow this place up, you'll destroy the time barrier equipment, and then their troops will be able to get in.
Yes, she's right. But we can keep the place guarded. You, get a machine gun and set it up in here. Right, come on.
That's all very well, but it's not going to get the Doctor back, is it.
The prisoner is in the security room awaiting interrogation.
Good. A very successful venture. Congratulations.
Thank you.
Give it to the scientist. He will return to the home planet and have it mass produced.
Very well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Security Chief leaves with the mind-washing machine.

Dialogue.Line: The interrogation of that resistance leader might prove difficult.
Why?
He is obviously a man of substantial intellect. He will need special treatment.
Then you must see he gets it, mustn't you?
I will.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Security Chief is using his mind-reading machine on the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Answer me. You must answer. Admit that the War Chief sent you here. You are both of the same race. Your arrival here is part of a plot to betray us to the Time Lords. Answer!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sits still so the Chief turns up the intensity.

Dialogue.Line: You will answer me now or I will destroy your mind totally!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Russell and two Americans set up a machine gun.

Dialogue.Line: Right, lads. Now see that this place is guarded at all times.
Machine gun set up, sir.
Fine.
Aye, maybe now you'll do something about getting the Doctor back?
I've got more than your friend the Doctor to worry about, lad.
Now look, we can't just leave him, you know.
If there was any way of helping him, I would.
We must carry out the Doctor's plan, that's the best way we can help him.
How far did you two get to contacting the other resistance groups?
Not very far, sir. The attack on this place got in the way.
Yeah.
We sent out guards to contact the other resistance groups, the ones we couldn't reach.
Can you remember their names?
Yes. There's Marcus Octavius from the Roman Zone, Arturo Villar from the Mexican Civil War Zone, Ivan Petrov from the Crimean war Zone.
Yes. All right, all right, I believe you.
And I can remember all the locations of all their camps, too.
Arturo Villar. Now he's the one we've got to convince.
Arturo Villar? Well, what's so special about him?
He's got one of the biggest resistance groups I know about. Bandits, most of them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A SIDRAT is materialising.

Dialogue.Line: Right, lads. Now don't fire until the door opens.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door opens and a guard comes out.

Dialogue.Line: Fire!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The machine gun is aimed directly at the opening, but the guard gets back in safely and the door closes.

Dialogue.Line: Hold it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A door opens again and the gunners are felled by a weapon. Russell manages to get out of the way in time. Carstairs enters.

Dialogue.Line: Get back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Russell takes the machine gun but Carstairs goes to the side of the SIDRAT and tosses a grenade in through the open door. BOOM. The SIDRAT dematerialises with smoke still curling from it.

Dialogue.Line: Well, they won't try that again in a hurry.
Soldier, get him out of here. Sergeant, get another machine gunner.
What happened?
It's all right, panic's over. Zoe, you'd better get a hurry with those resistance names, if you would.
Right.
What're you going to do then?
We've got to round them all up. Get them here for a meeting.
Oh, let's go then.
Not you, Jamie.
Eh?
Someone's got to be in charge here.
Me?
Yes, lad. You.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The interrogation is getting nowhere.

Dialogue.Line: Admit it, the War Chief sent for you. At this volume your mind will only last for fifteen minutes. Thirty if you are lucky. Now, admit that the War Chief sent for you!
Are you trying to kill him?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Security Chief turns off the probe and the Doctor relaxes.

Dialogue.Line: I am trying to get the truth out of him.
You'll never make him talk that way.
You are very sure.
He is one of my own race. Your truth machine cannot work on us if we choose to resist.
You admit it then. You do know him.
Of course I do. And only I can deal with him. Release him.
He is my prisoner.
But I am your superior.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Security Chief releases the Doctor's wrists from the chair.

Dialogue.Line: You and I are going to talk alone.
I have nothing to say to you.
We shall see. Guards, take this prisoner to the War Room.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is taken out.

Dialogue.Line: You have no right to interrupt my interrogation.
Your interrogation has been completely unsuccessful. I have methods of my own.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief leaves. The Security Chief goes over to his control desk.

Dialogue.Line: I want to speak to the War Lord on the top security channel.
See I am not interrupted. You also, outside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: All the technicians leave.

Dialogue.Line: You may have changed your appearance, but I know who you are.
Oh, do you?
Your machine is a Tardis. You're too familiar with it's controls to be a stranger.
I had every right to leave.
Stealing a Tardis? Oh, I'm not criticising you. We are two of a kind.
We most certainly are not!
We were both Time Lords and we both decided to leave our race.
I had reasons of my own.
Just as I had.
Your reasons are only too obvious. Power!
How much have you learnt of our plans?
I know that you've been kidnapping soldiers from the Earth from various times in it's history and bringing them here to kill one another.
But do you realise our ultimate objectives?
No objective can justify such slaughter.
The war games on this planet are simply the means to an end. The aliens intend to conquer the entire galaxy. A thousand inhabited worlds.
Yes, but why choose the people of the Earth?
They are the most suitable recruits for our armies. Man is the most vicious species of all.
Well, that simply isn't true.

Consider their history. For a half a million years they have been systematically killing each other. Now we can turn this savagery to some purpose. We can bring peace to the galaxy, and you can help. You see, I'm not the cold-hearted villain you suppose me to be. My motives are purely peaceful.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe has fallen asleep at the desk so Jamie puts a coat over her shoulders and leaves quietly. The armed guards are also dozing off. Then one gets hit over the head and the other has a rifle barrel pushed in his chest.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie? What?
You don't speak, make a noise, understand? This man Russell, where is he?
Who are you?
Arturo Villar!
Well, why didn't you tell us you were coming?
Traps are for animals to fall into. Hey, get the men Russell, and no tricks. My men surround this place.
Well, I think you might at least have a
Women should never think. For such a little woman your mouth is too big. Get Russell.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is asleep on the cot bed.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie?
Has something happened?
I'll say it has. Arturo Villar's arrived with all his bandits, and they've surrounded the headquarters.
Has he now? I'll soon sort him out.
Oh Jamie, no! They'd shoot you as soon as look at you.
Eh? I thought he was supposed to be on our side?
Well, he is. Well, I mean, he will be if we can persuade him to join us.
Well, didn't you explain to him?
Yes, I tried, but he wouldn't listen. He's got rather primitive ideas about women knowing their place.
Has he now? Oh, sounds a nice chap.
Jamie, this is no laughing matter. We've got to persuade him to stay here until Russell gets back.
Well look, if he won't listen to you, then he's not going to
No, not to me, but. Quickly over here, I've got an idea.
Zoe, what are you doing?
Jamie, come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Villar has helped himself to food.

Dialogue.Line: Well? Where is this Russell?
He's not here.
Then I go.
Wait! I think perhaps you'd better meet our other leader.
Who is this?
Jamie! Our leader, James Robert McCrimmon!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Wearing an officer's cap and with two ammo belts across his chest, Jamie swaggers in.

Dialogue.Line: Salut!
Oh, how do you do.
So, you call everyone together for a meeting, huh? Why? Maybe you plan to take over my territory, huh?
Oh, no, no. No, it's nothing like that, no.
Unity is strength.
Unity is strength.
And when you have this strength, what do you do with it?
Ah, do with it. Aye.
We attack the aliens that brought everybody here.
We attack them all together in force!
You bring all the resistance together in one place, you know what happens? We rob and kill each other!
You'll never win unless you work together. It's the only way.
Why do you let a woman speak for you?
Well, why not? Only if she's right, of course.
And I am.
We always fight in small groups, far apart. That's why they don't catch us.
Aye, and that's why you're getting nowhere.
We are free men. We do anything we want to.
You are hunted fugitives and they'll pick you off one by one unless you join with us. It's the only way you'll ever get home.
Home? No one can get away from this place.
Oh, but you can.
How?
The same way you all came here. But first we've got to defeat the people that run everything. They have a stronghold.
I have heard. It is impossible to get in there.
Well, we have been there, and if we can get a big enough army together, I can take you all there.
All right, I stay for this meeting. But then we see.
We have soldiers from most of the major wars in the planet Earth. The first World War, the war between Russia and Japan of 1905, Thirty years war.
But why make them kill each other?
How else can we find the most disciplined and courageous fighters?
You have given these aliens our science and our knowledge to carry out this disgusting plan.
We are going to bring a new order to the galaxy, one United Galactic Empire.
An empire of slaves, with you as one of it's rulers.
Doctor, this is also a matter of your own survival. Unless I can convince the War Lord that you will help us

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Alarms sound, the War Lord and Security Chief enter with guards.

Dialogue.Line: What is the prisoner doing here?
I am interrogating him.
You interrogate without guards?
I know this man. He is a fugitive from the Time Lords.
As you are.
That's right, as I am.
Did you bring him here?
No, he arrived by chance.
Did the Time Lords send you?
No.
Have you informed them?
He dare not. That would betray him.
He has allied himself with the resistance and has organised them against us. He must die.
No! He has agreed to help us destroy the resistance. He will cooperate. He has no alternative.
He should be killed now. We cannot trust him.
If he helps us destroy the resistance. If. His life will be spared.
War Lord.
I have decided. (to War Chief) I hold you responsible for the success of the plan. Failure will mean death, to both of you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Lord, Security Chief and guards leave.

Dialogue.Line: I never promised to help you!
But you will. You have no alternative.
But to help people like that to conquer the galaxy?
Not people like that, people like us. I intend to take over as Supreme Galactic Ruler. You can help me to rule, if you will cooperate.
I tell you it's crazy, it'll never work!
We don't know till we've tried it. We've never had all the resistance groups together before.
You bring everyone together in one place, you know what happens? The enemy will go pow! We are all killed.
What he says makes sense. Alone, we annoy them a little, together, we wipe them out.
That's exactly what the Doctor says.
Look, we should get together a large body of men. Armed, disciplined. And then, and only then can we strike at their headquarters.
How do we get there?
We use one of their own space time machines.
Ah, these little boxes you talk about, holding thousands of men. Fairy stories!
I have seen one. I have seen soldiers come out of them. Whole regiments.
You see, Señor Villar? We're not talking nonsense.
These magic boxes. Where do we get one?
They have certain landing points in each time zone. That room over there, that's one of them.
How you get a whole army in here? The place is surrounded. It's hard enough for one man at a time to get in.
Yes, quite right. We must use one of the other places.
Well, what about that American barn where we met Mister Russell?
Yes, that's er, that's here. (points to map) Is that all right for everybody?
Khorosho! I know that place. Much forest, easy to hide men.
Well, we're agreed then. You all gather your groups here, and we make a concerted attack on the enemy.
And what if he make a concerted attack on us?
Oh, he's going to be far too busy to do that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A motley pair of resistance fighters sneak into a Roman tent and smash its communications unit.
Zone One alarm sounds.

Dialogue.Line: Failure of communications unit in Roman Zone. Send a technicians to repair. And send a guard!
Right. Good. Right, carry on. That's the first one, Roman Zone. Control unit's been completely destroyed.
I wonder if it'll work?
Oh, it'll work all right. Next one's due in the Crimean War Zone. It's due about now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The poor sentry gets jumped and dragged away while a Mexican takes dynamite into the store room. He comes out again unrolling the fuse wire which his Redcoat companion fastens to the detonator and then presses the plunger. KaBOOM!

Dialogue.Line: Another communications failure. Crimean War Zone. Send a squad of guards!
(answers telephone.) Hello. Russell.
(on telephone) Good. Excellent. Yes, thank you very much.
I see.
Roman Zone. A technician and guard have arrived.
So that's the Roman Zone then.
Technician and guard? That's only two men.
They're not really worried yet.
They are now. They've just sent a squad of guards to the Crimean War Zone.
Oh, good. That's a more like it.
By the time we've finished with them, there won't be a guard left in the place.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Time passes, and flags are put on the map for Russo-Japanese war and 30 years war. Zoe takes a call.

Dialogue.Line: Good! Jamie, Boer War Zone.
English Civil War Zone.
Yes, fine. Peninsular War Zone, they've sent ten guards there.
Right, well, that seems to be about it. Right, time for phase two. Villar should be at the barn by now. Carry on, Sergeant.
Sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Okay, we'll leave one by one and spread out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A soldier rushes in and goes straight to the video screen. He gets shot. A Mexican draws his pistol to shoot out the screen.

Dialogue.Line: No, not yet. Now we wait.
It is a clear pattern. Simultaneous attacks in all time zones.
And you've sent guards to every attack?
There are now very few left to send.
That's exactly what they wanted. Have any of the guards returned?
No.
So you've left the base weakened for a possible mass attack.
Is that true?
I know where their attack is coming from. A communications unit was activated in the American Civil War Zone.
And how do you propose to deal with them, with your guards scattered all over the War Zones?
The neutron bomb.
That would wipe out the processed humans. We would have to evacuate the planet.
The resistance army must be crushed once and for all.
So we shall use the neutron bomb?
No, we shall attempt to be rather more subtle than that, (to the Doctor) which will give you an ideal opportunity to prove your loyalty and save your life.
Are all the resistance groups here, Sergeant?
Yes, sir.
They are hidden in the woods. So here we all are in one place, a nice big target.
Don't worry, it won't be for long. Soon as we smash that thing, they'll send one of their machines and we'll take it.
Right, stand back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs is about to shoot out the video screen when a familiar face appears on it.

Dialogue.Line: Wait a minute! DOCTOR [on monitor]: Jamie? Zoe?
Oh Doctor, where are you? Are you all right? DOCTOR [on monitor]: Is Mister Russell there?

Aye, all the resistance leaders are with us. DOCTOR [on monitor]: Oh, good. Now there's no time to be lost. I think I can send you one of their space time machines. I've managed to gain control of their transportation system.

We've got a whole army here, Doctor. We could take over the entire base. DOCTOR [on monitor]: Oh, no, no. All I need is a party of picked men. There's got quite a lot to organise. I have to talk to the leaders.
But Doctor, would it not be better if we brought a gang with us? DOCTOR [on monitor]: Jamie, please don't argue. I will send the transportation now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ends.

Dialogue.Line: I don't like this. It could be a trap.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A SIDRAT materialises.

Dialogue.Line: Don't panic! There's nothing to worry about. Everybody take cover just in case there are some guards.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The SIDRAT door opens and Carstairs checks inside.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right. It's empty.
Right, now one of us must stay here to look after those men. Petrov, it'd better be you.
All right, you are boss.
Mine is the biggest group. I should stay here in charge.
Why? You scared of going into that thing?
Arturo Villar is afraid of nothing!
Right. In you go then.
I shall lead the way. (Carstairs, Villar, Zoe, Jamie, Russell enter the SIDRAT followed by Russell and a couple of soldiers. It dematerialises.)
What's happened?
We were idiots to trust you. I'll kill you for this!
Idle threats, Doctor, have no fear. Guards, disarm them and take them away.
Take him too.
No. He is working for us.
What further use is he?
He has proved his loyalty by helping us, and he has great knowledge of time travel mechanics.
The War Lord shall decide. Take these prisoners to the processing room. Hold them there under strict guard until further orders.
Get off!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The prisoners are hustled away.

Dialogue.Line: I shall be with the War Lord.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Security Chief leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Don't worry, Doctor. The War Lord will welcome your loyalty and assistance.
Well, I hope so, but you know, I find it hard to understand why you need me.
We need each other.
It's something to do with the Tardis travel machines, isn't it?
Shall we join the War Lord? It doesn't do to keep him waiting.
I must congratulate you on them, you know. You're achieved a remarkable degree of control.
Simply a variation on the old models.
Oh, my dear fellow, you're too modest. Dimensional flexibility? Remote control? In my day these things were impossible to achieve without shortening the life of the time control units.
There have been many advances made in space time technology.
Yes, there must have been. That particular problem is impossible to solve. How did you solve it?
It's not a thing one can explain in a few words. We'll discuss it later. Now we really should join the War Lord.
You haven't solved it, have you? Your machines have a limited life span. Sooner or later they're going to be useless.
Very well. Yes, you're right.
Now I understand. It's my Tardis that you're after, isn't it?
Exactly! When we are in control, the machines I have brought with me will have expired. If we hold the only space time travel machine, we can rule our galaxy without fear of opposition.
Yes, but without me and my Tardis your ambitions are going to be rather hard to realise, aren't they?
That's right. And without my influence, these aliens will surely kill you.
Well, a fine mess your friend the Doctor got us in, eh? I'll break his neck when I get my hands on him.
Oh, I don't believe it.
Look, he must have had a good reason.
To have us killed, maybe, to save his own skin. When I get my hands on him I kill him too!
Now look, the Doctor wouldn't betray us.
No, of course, he wouldn't! Why did he get us to come here?
He seems to have done very well. We have the leaders of the resistance, and the immediate threat to the war games is over. But your sudden decision to join us worries me.
Well, I like to be on the winning side.
Previously you thought the resistance to be the winning side. What made you change your mind?
Well, I hadn't realised how small and weak their groups were compared with your might and power.
You have a silver tongue, just like your friend the War Chief. What contribution can you make to our plan?
Well, your processing machines. I can make them work more effectively.
Our scientist is at this moment producing new machines on the home planet.
Ah yes, but that will take time. I can make the old ones work just as well. Probably better.
Very well. You shall have the opportunity to prove your ability. You will adjust the machines and reprocess your resistance friends.
They are no longer my friends. They are our enemies.
Of course they are. Take him to the processing room. See he has every facility.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Security Chief leave with guards.

Dialogue.Line: The resistance groups, where are they?
They are all now concentrated in this one area. I have ordered the conventional troops to move in on them.
Good. When the situation returns to normal order all the security guards to return to the control centre. All control points on the planet are to be repaired, and the war games recommenced.
Are you returning to the home planet?
No. I'm waiting until the emergency is over. You will inform me immediately if there's any change in the situation.
What are they making us wait here for?
Probably going to reprocess us again.
Eh?
Brainwash us, send us back to fight.
No, I doubt it. They know their processing machines don't work on us.
They will shoot us. What else do you do with prisoners?
Your friend the Doctor has a better idea. He is going to adjust the machines and re-process you himself.
He wouldn't do that!
Doctor, you can't!
You just try it!
I don't think they like you. Unfortunately I cannot spare any of my guards to protect you, so you will have to fend for yourself.
What? But you

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Security Chief leaves with the guards.

Dialogue.Line: Well, well, well. It seems your new friends don't like you either.
Leave him to me. I kill him first.
No. No! Don't come any closer, no!
How is the battle progressing?
The resistance group were all concentrated in this one area. We have them completely encircled.
And now you will destroy them?
Of course. They are falling into disorder, naturally enough since we have their leaders here. Has the Doctor started processing them?
Not yet.
Why not?
Where is the War Lord?
You did take the Doctor to the processing room?
Of course.
I don't trust you.
The feeling is mutual.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Play back the recordings.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is being mobbed.

Dialogue.Line: Oh no, leave me alone!
Leave him be!
Now look! Just give him a chance to speak!
Yes, we listened to him once before and look where it got us. He led us into a trap!
They were going to drop a neutron bomb! You'd all be dead now, and all of your resistance friends with you, if it wasn't for me.
He's lying.
You did a deal to save your own neck.
But your deal didn't do you no good. They turn you over to us and now we kill you.
No, you can't just murder him.
Is not murder, is execution.
Have you got any explanation for your conduct?
Yes, I am trying to save your lives! If you do exactly as I tell you'll be all right.
We don't listen to your lies no more.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Villar gets away from Carstairs and starts choking the Doctor. The War Chief and his guards break it up.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry, Doctor. There seems to have been some kind of misunderstanding.
Yes, and it was very nearly fatal.
Doctor, this is also a matter of your own survival. Unless I can convince the War Lord that you will help us
Stop! Wind further on. Now! Try there.
Responsible for the success of the plan. Failure will mean death. For both of you.
I never promised to help you!
But you will. You have no alternative.
To help people like that gain control of the galaxy?
Not people like that, people like us. I will take over as Supreme Galactic Ruler. You can help me rule, if you will cooperate.
Enough! I knew it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is in the brainwashing machine.

Dialogue.Line: Are you sure this new process will be completely effective?
Oh yes, quite sure. I think that will do. There we are. Now then, when this young man comes to, he will believe himself to be fighting the English Redcoats in 1745. Now get up!
Eh? Oh.
What is your name?
Eh?
Your name.
Ah, James Robert McCrimmon.
Do you know where you are?
Er well, I
You are in my castle. I am the McCrimmon of McCrimmon, your hereditary Chieftain.
Yes, of course. You're the Chieftain. Who's that?
Well, that is a friendly chieftain. You will obey his orders as you will mine.
Oh aye, I'll obey you.
There you are, you see? Complete loyalty and devotion. I can do the same with all the other resistance people that you capture.
Excellent. Continue with the others. If you can successfully process characters like these, you will have made an immense contribution.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you. Bring the girl!
Oh, leave me alone. Don't!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards bring Zoe, and Jamie helps sit her down.

Dialogue.Line: Look, do as you're told.
You will obey us. It is for your own good. (wink)
What a stupid fool you are. You deliberately disobeyed the War Lord's orders. Arrest him. Arrest him!
You are no longer in command.
I will take over as Supreme Galactic Ruler. You can help me rule, if you will cooperate.

I had all discussion that took place between you and the Doctor recorded. What a stupid fool you are. Guards, take him to the security bay! Collect his accomplice, the Doctor, on the way. If they offer any resistance, shoot them both!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Villar has been processed.

Dialogue.Line: There we are. Now then, sit up, sit up! Now then, you are in la Castille de la Cruz de San Antonio de la Frada Forma, in Mexico.
Eh? Are you crazy? You machine is no good! Villar is too strong for you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Villar starts throttling the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Stop! Get him off me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs and the others tackle the guards who come to his aid, then Jamie gets Villar off the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Can you not pretend like the rest of us, you great loon?
Is all a trick?
Aye.
You fix the machine so she don't work?
Yes. I fix her, and you nearly fixed me.
And you only pretend to be loco?
Exactly!
But Doctor, why did you get us here at all?
They were going to drop the neutron bomb. You were better alive here than dead out there.
Zoe, watch the door, will you?
Right.
Doctor, now we're here, surely we can take over?
It depends upon how many of those guards they've got.
Ah, but we've been drawing them out to the Time Zones.
Yes, very successfully from what I hear.
Doctor, somebody's coming. Three of them are heading this way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief is marched in under guard. The fighters take out the guards.

Dialogue.Line: Don't harm him. We may need him.
It seems my trust in you was a little misplaced.
Did you really think I'd take part in your disgusting, stealing scheme?
Why not? You must have been a little tempted by the thought of being the ruler of an entire galaxy.
All this talk! When we fight?
We haven't got anything to fight with. We've no guns.
We've got those alien guns if we can work out how to use them.
I no trust those things. I need my guns, they good guns, never miss.
Well, he knows where they're stored.
I might.
You'd better, because I'm
I'm sure that the War Chief is going to cooperate. He's going to help us gain control of the War Room.
That may not be so easy. You see, our little arrangement had been discovered. I was under arrest.
Oh yes?
Yes, that could be right. He did come in here under gunpoint.
But the personnel in the landing bay are not aware of my arrest. When the security guards return from the Time Zones, you won't stand a chance. I can stop the arrival of the time machines.
I see. Very well, but first you'll take us to the War Room. You're the only one that can stop the fighting in the Zones.
Hey, wait a minute! First we get our guns, no?
No. I mean, yes. Come along, Jamie, Zoe.

I want a blanket broadcast to all security guards in the War Zones. This is the Security Chief. The resistance groups are scattered over the Civil War Zone. They will be dealt with later. All security guards will now proceed to the nearest control point, there are

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The resistance rushes in.

Dialogue.Line: Guards!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two more guards enter, and Villar shoots them.

Dialogue.Line: I told you, my guns best!
Emergency alarm!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The technician hits the alarm then gets shot. The Security Chief tries to sneak to a weapons rack, and the War Chief takes him down with one of the sonic weapons. Jamie and Carstairs point their guns at him.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right. It was a personal debt I had to settle.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief hands over the weapon.

Dialogue.Line: Will somebody turn off that hideous noise? I cannot think!
There's one thing I don't understand, Doctor. How are you going to get all these people back to their own time?
Yes, I've been thinking about that.
You realise that we have very little time now the alarm has been sounded?
Yes. Call off the fighting at once!
We could just go to the landing bay, order a machine and leave.
You could, we can't. The fighting has to be stopped and everyone sent back to their own times.
Sent back? How?
By your Tardis travel machines, of course.
I'm afraid that will not be possible. There are only two machines left with enough life in them.
What? But, oh my word, well that's happened rather sooner than I expected.
Doctor, does that mean that you can't do as you promised and get us all home?
Oh, well, yes, I
You can't.
I can still do that.
You can't, unless. Doctor, you mustn't call them in or it will be the end of us. They'll show no mercy.
You stop the fighting!
Do as you're told!
This is the War Chief to all War Zones. This is a command direct from the War Lord. All fighting will cease. I repeat, all fighting in the War Zones will cease. You will stand by for further orders.
What did he mean, Doctor? Who mustn't you call?
The only people who can put an end to this whole ghastly business and send everyone back to their own times. The Time Lords.
Who are they?
They're my own people, Jamie.
Oh, well, that's all right, then.
But it isn't all right, is it, Doctor.
No, it's not, Zoe. But I'm afraid that there's no alternative.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sits on the floor and puts six plastic squares in a circle in front of him. Then he closes his eyes and concentrates.

Dialogue.Line: What's he doing?
Don't do it, Doctor. You can't! You know what will happen!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The squares form themselves into a cube.

Dialogue.Line: Look at that!
That's fantastic.
Is magic!
Doctor, are you all right?
Yes, Zoe, I'm all right.
Doctor, what's that?
It's a box, Jamie.
I know. I can see that.
It's a very special sort of box. It now contains all the information about what's been going on here, and an appeal for help.
Help? Who from?
The Time Lords?
Yes, Zoe.
Well, why haven't you asked them for help before?
I've never really needed it before, Jamie, but this business of sending everyone back to their own times is, well, it's too difficult for me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts the cube in his pocket.

Dialogue.Line: Now, come along. The War Chief!
What?
He's gone!
What?
He must be trying to get away before the Time Lords get here!
Well, what are we going to do, Doctor?
We must go to the landing bay and stop him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief runs in and summons a SIDRAT. But before he can get inside he is stopped by guards.

Dialogue.Line: I thought
Yes?
You've arrived just in time. There's been a revolt. The prisoners have escaped. How many guards do you have?
Only the ones you see here.
Then we must return to the home planet to bring reinforcements.
Where is the Security Chief?
The prisoners have taken over the War Room. They've killed him.
No, no, you killed him, but a little too late. I heard the recording.
He wanted to stop the War Games. He was a incompetent fool, jealous of my position. Surely you realise that? He forged that recording you heard.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief runs for the exit but guards block him.

Dialogue.Line: He wanted to stop the war games! He tried
Kill him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Chief's screams can be heard.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor! Doctor, that came from the landing bay!
Yes, but they won't be expecting us. Come on.
Remove the traitor's carcass. We will return to the home planet and bring back an army to quell this revolt once and for all.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards take the War Chief's body to one side while the War Lord adjusts the SIDRAT control panel.

Dialogue.Line: Viva el Villar!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Villar starts shooting, and the other fighters join in from the other side of the bay. Jamie goes hand to hand with a remaining guard.

Dialogue.Line: Out of the way, I shoot the dog!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carstairs deals with the other surviving guard as Russell helps Jamie. Villar goes to the War Lord.

Dialogue.Line: I kill him too!
No, no, that won't be necessary. We'll leave him for the Time Lords to dispose of.
When will they be here, Doctor?
I'm going to send for them now. And I want you all to stay here and wait until they come.
But what are you going to do?
Well, I cannot stay here. Jamie, Zoe, this is where we say goodbye.
What are you talking about?
Well, the Time Lords will return you home.
But why can't we stay with you?
Because when I send this box to them, they'll know where I am.
But I thought they were your people, your friends?
Yes, Jamie, they are my people, but. Oh, it'd take too long to explain. I have to go!
Now look, if you're going to be in trouble, you'll need me to look after you.
Me, too.
Aye.
But you don't understand! Oh, very well, but don't say I didn't warn you. Right then, we must return to the 1917 Zone and find the Tardis, and make good our escape.
Doctor, can I come back there with you? I'd rather like to try and find Lady Jennifer.
Oh yes, very well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gets a SIDRAT ready, then sits on the floor and concentrates. The box vanishes.

Dialogue.Line: Well, goodbye, gentlemen. I'm sorry, but we must rush.
You leave us?
Yes, what about us?
The Time Lords will return you home. Now come along.
No! No one is going anywhere. This Doctor, he cheat us. We rescue him and now he leave us here to die.
Yes, it's only fair, Doctor! If these Time Lords are friends of yours, why don't you wait for them to arrive?
But you don't understand, Mister Russell. I must go. Please!
You stay here with us, my friend.
Look, I am not going to argue. Jamie, Zoe, Carstairs, into the machine.
Ah but Doctor, look, he's not joking, you know.
For once, Jamie, do as you are told!
You move and I kill you!
Then you will just have to kill me, Mister Villar.
Well Mister Doctor, that is just what I will do!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes into the SIDRAT after Jamie and Zoe. Carstairs and Russell grab Villar to stop him shooting the Doctor, then Carstairs enters the SIDRAT.

Dialogue.Line: Let me go, I kill him!
You can't shoot him in the back, he's done too much for us.
Ah, the back, the front, what's the difference?
It's too late now, anyway.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The SIDRAT dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: Don't worry. When the Time Lords get him, he'll wish you had killed him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A strange sound fills the room.

Dialogue.Line: They're coming.
What's happening, Doctor? I can hardly move.
It's a force field. Concentrate. We may be able to break through it. Help me with the key. Concentrate!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie holds the Doctor's arm up to turn the key and open the Tardis door.
They crawl inside.

Dialogue.Line: It's in here, too.
Will we get away all right, Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor reaches the door controls.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, I hope so, Jamie. If I can boost the power enough, the Tardis may be able to break through the force field.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis dematerialises and they can move at normal speed again.

Dialogue.Line: Well, what was happening? Why was it so difficult to move?
It was the Time Lords.
But they're your own people, aren't they, Doctor?
Yes, that's right.
Why did you run away from them in the first place?
What? Well, I was bored.
What do you mean, you were bored?
Well, the Time Lords are an immensely civilised race. We can control our own environment, we can live forever, barring accidents, and we have the secret of space time travel.
Well what's so wrong in all that?
Well we hardly ever use our great powers. We consent simply to observe and to gather knowledge.
And that wasn't enough for you?
No, of course not. With a whole galaxy to explore? Millions of planets, eons of time, countless civilisations to meet?
Well, why do they object to you doing all that?
Well, It is a fact, Jamie, that I do tend to get involved with things.
Aye, you can say that again. Whenever there's any trouble, he's in it right up to his neck.
But you've helped people, Doctor.
Yes, yes, but that's no excuse in their eyes.
Well, then what are you going to do?
We're going to run away. I've set the controls to take us to a planet on the outermost fringes of the galaxy.
Oh, in that case, we'll probably land up right in their laps.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: We can't be landing already.
Well, that is impossible!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The TARDIS is dropping through the air to a sea, where it lands with a gentle plop.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's the sea.
Well, don't worry, Jamie. We know the Tardis can't sink.
Oh, can't it? Look!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scanner is looking straight at a coral reef.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, now what can we do?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A shark swims by.

Dialogue.Line: Look out!
It's all right. It can't possibly harm us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A type of materialisation noise sounds and the Tardis shakes.

Dialogue.Line: I'm not so sure!
We're perfectly safe in the Tardis.
Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Water is dripping onto the console.

Dialogue.Line: Oh my word! It's the Time Lords. They're breaking down the defensive mechanism. We've got to get out of here.
Where can we go?
Well, I know one place where we'll be safe, if I can get us there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor relocates the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Where are we?
We're in outer space. We'll just stop here for a while. There's a chance we may have given them the slip.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A gentle, reasonable voice fills the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: There is no escape, Doctor. Return the Tardis immediately to our home planet.
Why can't you leave me alone? I haven't done any harm.
You have broken our laws. You must face your trial.
Trial?
You will do better to return of your own accord.
Oh, oh, oh, very well, if I must.
Doctor, what on Earth are you doing?
I'm trying to make a quick transference jump. We've got to get away from here to somewhere safe. Ah, we're landing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scanner shows alligators.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, no!
Is that what you call somewhere safe?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The trio are thrown to the floor.

Dialogue.Line: Oh! It's shaking itself to pieces!
Yeah, we could all be killed!
Doctor, can't you induce a power drive?
I'll try. Oh, the controls. They're moving by themselves.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everything settles down again.

Dialogue.Line: Now where are we?
Oh, let's see on the scanner.
Oh, it's broken.
No, I don't think so.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Suddenly the picture resolves itself into a long chamber filled with SIDRATS along one wall.

Dialogue.Line: You have returned to us, Doctor. Your travels are over.
It's my own planet. They have brought us here.
Can't we get away again?
No, not this time. Come along.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man in a long robe is waiting for them.

Dialogue.Line: Come with me.
Now, just a moment. What's going on around here?
Jamie, do as he says.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They are led in. The War Lord is already there. The Time Lord joins two others.

Dialogue.Line: The witnesses have arrived.
Let them stand aside until they are needed. Continue with the trial.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yes, that mellifluous voice is  Bernard Horsfall again.

Dialogue.Line: In every one of these time zones, thousands of human beings fought and died in the belief that they were on their own planet. The survivors have now all been returned to their own times on the planet Earth, but the death roll is beyond counting. These lives were squandered in the course of a vicious and diabolical scheme to gain control of the entire galaxy. A scheme originated and devised by a race of which the accused is the leader. It was a was a highly organised scheme with an utterly callous disregard for the lives of the humans involved and for the liberties of all the other species in the galaxy which the accused would have dominated with his tyranny. In the pursuit of this scheme, brutal methods of mental processing were used which entirely contravened all the galactic laws. I will now call upon a member of our own race to sort this evil matter out. There will commence a reading of the witness' report. The witness is called. Will you step forward, please?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Over the above statement, the Doctor is explaining.

Dialogue.Line: The Time Lords holding a trial is a very rare event.
Why?
Well, normally they don't interfere with the affairs of other planets, but they had to when I called for help.
Well, look, can't we get away?
Well, you and Zoe may, but I don't think I will. TIME LORD 3: Will you step forward, please?
Oh, oh, I beg your pardon. TIME LORD 3: We have received your statement. Do you swear to the truth of your report?
Everything in that report is the result of my direct personal observation. TIME LORD 3: Who is that person?
That is the War Lord. TIME LORD 3: Does the accused have anything to say?
You must speak in your defence. TIME LORD 2: The trial cannot proceed unless you do. TIME LORD 3: You must speak.
Can't you see he's just playing for time? TIME LORD 3: Do not make us force you to speak. We would not cause you unnecessary pain. Very well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Time Lord widens his eyes and suddenly the War Lord falls to his knees screaming and clutching his head.

Dialogue.Line: Stop it! Stop the light! TIME LORD 3: You must speak.
Yes. TIME LORD 3: Do you admit the charges with which you have been accused?
I do not even admit the authority of this court.
Have you anything to say in your defence?
The humans who died in our war games would have killed each other anyway. TIME LORD 2: Is your plea that that ends justifies the means?

Yes, it is. And members of your own race agreed with me. My War Chief was himself was a Time Lord, and the knowledge he brought me made the whole scheme possible. And another of your Time Lords gave me his support!
I never supported your scheme for one moment.
You collaborated with my War Chief. If I am guilty, then you are guilty too!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile, two men are inside the Tardis, working on the console. One goes out to investigate the sound of materialisation and is gunned down by two of the War Lord's guards. The second then comes out and is also killed. Then a total of six guards move off.

Dialogue.Line: We find you guilty of all charges against you. Your attempt to incriminate others is an obvious fraud.
Oh, good. I'm glad to see your sense of justice still prevails.

Dialogue.Character: (sotto) Even though they've lost their sense of humour. WAR LORD
Dialogue.Line: You have no authority over me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards enter.

Dialogue.Line: And no power any longer to pass any sentence. Take these people.
Oh, no!
Not again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Zoe and Jamie are hustled out.

Dialogue.Line: And if any attempt is made to stop us, then I shall kill them instantly.
Let them go. We shall not endanger innocent lives.
You'll never get away. The Time Lords are too strong for you. You needn't think I'm going to help you.
Oh yes, you will help us, Doctor, if you want to save the lives of your two friends. Now, into the machine.
Look, the Tardis is no good to you. He can't even steer it properly.
Don't talk rubbish. Of course he can steer it. Now, into the machine!
Yes, you shall make us many of these machines. Now, get to the control panel and take us back to the home planet.
I can't, I tell you. The directional mechanism is faulty.
You will do as I say or we shall kill the girl.
But I don't even know where your home planet is.
Galactic sector nine seven three, then we will get the homing signal. Now operate the machine!
I'll do my best, but I can't promise anything. Jamie, Zoe, hide your eyes. Run!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis lights are blinding.

Dialogue.Line: Get after them! Kill them! Quickly!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Jamie and Zoe run over to the Time Lords.

Dialogue.Line: Kill them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But a forcefield stops the guards.

Dialogue.Line: A force field has been placed around you, and around your planet, so that your warlike people will remain prisoners forever. You have been found guilty of all charges, and you and your murderous associates will be dematerialised. It will be as though you had never existed.
No, no, no, no!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The War Lord and the guards vanish.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, well, that's put an end to them. Well, we'll be on our way. Come on, Doctor. Cheerio.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie strolls over to the Tardis and straight into the forcefield which then envelopes him and Zoe.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, switch this thing off.
Jamie, they are not going to let us go.
What? After all you've done for them?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and two Time Lords leave.

Dialogue.Line: What are you going to do to him? TIME LORD 3: He must stand his trial. You will wait here.
Well, we want to go with the Doctor! Oh, let us out!
Come on, let us out of this thing!
You have heard the charge against you, that you have repeatedly broken our most important law of non-interference in the affairs of other planets. What have you to say? Do you admit these actions?

I not only admit them, I am proud of them. While you have been content merely to observe the evil in the galaxy, I have been fighting against it. TIME LORD 3: It is not we who are on trial here, Doctor, it is you.
No, no, of course, you're above criticism, aren't you.
Do you admit that these actions were justified?
Yes, of course, I do. Give me a thought channel and I'll show you some of the evils I've been fighting against.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Time Lords nod to each other.

Dialogue.Line: The Quarks, deadly robot servants of the cruel Dominators, they tried to enslave a peace loving race. Then there were the Yeti, more robot killers, instruments of an alien intelligence trying to take over the planet Earth. TIME LORD 3: All this is entirely irrelevant.

You asked me to justify my actions, I am doing so. Let me show you the Ice Warriors, cruel Martian invaders, they tried to conquer the Earth too. So did the Cybermen, half creature, half machine. But worst of all were the Daleks, a pitiless race of conquerors exterminating all who came up against them. All these evils I have fought while you have done nothing but observe. True, I am guilty of interference, just as you are guilty of failing to use your great powers to help those in need!
Is that all you have to say?
Well, isn't it enough?
Your defence has been heard and will be carefully considered, but you have raised difficult issues. We require time to think about them. You will be recalled when we have made our decision.
Let us out!
We want to see the Doctor. Let us out of here!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The force field is turned off.

Dialogue.Line: Follow me.
Where are we going? TIME LORD 2: We're going to send you home. Back you your own world and your own time.
Oh no, not without the Doctor. TIME LORD 2: This is his world. He must stay here.
Well, what's going to happen to him? TIME LORD 2: He is awaiting the result of his trial.
Aye, well, I'm not going till I see him.
Oh, please, can't we see the Doctor? TIME LORD 2: You have become attached to him?
Aye, we've been through a lot, you know.
Please let us see him. TIME LORD 2: Come with me.
Aye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is reclining on the floor, playing clock patience.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie! Zoe!
Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They are stopped by a forcefield.

Dialogue.Line: I've brought your friends to say goodbye.
Oh, switch this thing off.
We can't say goodbye through a forcefield. TIME LORD 2: Very well. I shall leave you together. for a little while.
Oh, thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The forcefield disappears and the Time Lord leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie! Zoe!
Doctor!
What are they going to do to you?
Oh, nothing much. I expect they'll to make me listen to a long boring speech about being a good boy. They like making speeches.
Well, I think it's time you left them again.
Well, that's easier said than done.
Oh come on, we've been in tighter situations than this.
Well, you don't know the Time Lords, Jamie. I do.
Oh, you're not just going to give up, are you, Doctor?
Of course he's not. Are you, Doctor, eh?
Well. Oh, all right, but we may find it a bit difficult getting out of here.
Hey, they've forgotten to switch that thing back on again.
Forgotten?
Well, that's all we need, isn't it? Now we can get away.
Yes, yes, of course.
Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Jamie and Zoe pick their way through an area of square pools of mist to

Dialogue.Line: There is no escape, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie runs up against a forcefield.

Dialogue.Line: It is time to say goodbye to your friends.
There must be something we can do?
No Zoe, not this time. Well, goodbye, Jamie.
But Doctor surely we could
Goodbye, Jamie.
I won't forget you, you know.
I won't forget you. Don't go blundering into too much trouble, will you?
Oh, you're a fine one to talk.
Goodbye, Zoe.
Goodbye, Doctor. Will we ever meet again?
Again? Now, Zoe, you and I know, time is relative, isn't it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Zoe are led to a SIDRAT. They wave and go inside. It dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: They'll forget me, won't they? TIME LORD 2: Not entirely. They will be returned to a time just before they went away with you. They will remember their first adventure with you, but nothing more. But come along. Your fate has been decided.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor watches on the trial chamber viewscreen as a confused Zoe walks down a corridor.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Zoe. Zoe, are you all right?
Oh, yes.
Are the Doctor and Jamie gone?
Yes, I've just seen them off.
Well, we'd better get back to work, you know. There's a lot to be done if we're going to get the Wheel back to normal. Are you sure you're all right?
Oh, yes. I thought I'd forgotten something important, but it's nothing.
Right, come along then.
All right, I'm coming.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On the screen, Zoe looks back then the image fades.

Dialogue.Line: She'll be all right, won't she?
Of course.
What about Jamie? TIME LORD 3: Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Pipes are skirling as a Redcoat aims his musket at Jamie's back. He turns and drops just as the soldier fires.

Dialogue.Line: Try to murder a McCrimmon, would you? Well, I'll show you! Creag an Tuire!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie charges the Redcoat, swinging his sword while the man tries to reload. The soldier wisely gives up and flees.

Dialogue.Line: They will both continue their lives as if nothing had happened.
Yes, very efficient. Now then, what about me?
We have accepted your plea that there is evil in the universe that must be fought, and that you still have a part to play in that battle.
What? You mean that you're going to let me go free?
Not entirely. We have noted your particular interest in the planet Earth. The frequency of your visits must have given you special knowledge of that world and it's problems.
Yes, I suppose that's true. Earth seems more vulnerable than others, yes.
For that reason you will be sent back to that planet.
Oh, good.
In exile.
In exile?
You will be sent to Earth in the 20th century, and will remain there for as long as we deem proper, and for that period the secret of the Tardis will be taken from you.
But you, you can't condemn me to exile on one primitive planet in one century in time! Besides, I'm known on the Earth. It might be very awkward for me.
Your appearance has changed before, it will change again. That is part of the sentence.
You can't just change what I look like without consulting me!
You will have an opportunity to choose your appearance.
Oh, well, that's not so bad. But I warn you, I'm very particular.
Here is your first choice.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man with a big bushy beard, followed by other sketches.

Dialogue.Line: Oh he's too old! Well he's too fat, isn't he. No, he's too thin. That one's too young. Oh now, that won't do at all. It's ridiculous.
You're wasting time, Doctor.
It's not my fault, is it? Is this the best you can do? I've never seen such an incredible bunch.
Since you refuse to take the decision, the decision will be taken for you.
No, no, no, I never said that. But I maintain I have the right to decide what I look like! It could be very important on the Earth. People on Earth attach a very great deal of importance

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor's face is beginning to twist and change.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, what's happening?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: We are treated to multiple images of Patrick gurning as they circle around.

Dialogue.Line: What's hap, what's happened?
The time has come for you to change your appearance, Doctor, and begin your exile.
Is this some sort of joke? No, I refuse to be treated in. What are you doing?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor's face disappears.

Dialogue.Line: No! Stop, you're making me giddy! No, you can't do this to me! No, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no!
